fell at the Sarasota-Bradenton Airport in one hour is also a record -- and more rain is expected this week.\n\nA city on Florida's west coast was hit by a record-breaking 8 inches of rain in just three hours on Tuesday evening, bringing flash floods to the area, hindering drivers and delaying hundreds of flights across the state.\n\nSo rare was Tuesday's rain between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. in Sarasota that it should only be expected every 500 to 1,000 years. {"uri": "8175971057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "12:01:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T12:01:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T12:00:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/305886", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!,\" the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.", "source": {"uri": "naharnet.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Naharnet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-388518104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:43:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:43:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T08:03:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.firstcoastnews.com/article/news/regional/florida/florida-rainfall-flooding/67-a6c89d15-2a5e-47d8-b866-ef5615413b03", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.", "source": {"uri": "firstcoastnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTLV 12 - Jacksonville"}, "authors": [{"uri": "assets@firstcoastnews.com", "name": On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Hobe Sound, Florida"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Hobe Sound, Florida"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United "https://images.indianexpress.com/2024/06/florida-rain-feature.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644091", "eventUri": "eng-9644091", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2862745098039216, "wgt": 216, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8176144256", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:45:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:45:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:44:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.vindy.com/news/latest-news/2024/06/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "A man walks on a flooded street on his way to work, Thursday, June 13, 2024, in North Miami, Fla. A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida. Floridians prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday. (AP Photo/Marta Lavandier)\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall today and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early today that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!,\" the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches.\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through today. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nFrisaro reported from Fort Lauderdale. Associated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "vindy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Vindicator"}, "authors": [], "concepts": His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches.\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 216, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8175952439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:49:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:49:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T11:48:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.ksn.com/weather/weather-stories/ap-after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!,\" the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFrisaro reported from Fort Lauderdale. Associated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "ksn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSN-TV"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8175733468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:36:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:36:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:35:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/local/miami-dade/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "Related As heavy rain pummels South Florida, tow truck drivers keep busy with stalled carsFlorida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy delugeHeavy rainfall brings flash flood emergency to Miami-Dade and Broward; hundreds of delays, cancellations at MIA and FLL\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "https://wsvn.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2024/06/240613-After-rare-flash-flood-emergency-Florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8175290132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:09:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:09:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:08:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/us-dangerous-flooding-blocks-roads-delays-travel-in-florida-prompting-authorities-to-declare-emergency-8930996.html", "title": "US: Dangerous Flooding Blocks Roads, Delays Travel In Florida, Prompting Authorities To Declare Emergency - News18", "body": "The Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_emergency", {"uri": "8176051897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "12:50:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T12:50:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T12:48:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/492160/Florida-s-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Jim Comunale and Pam Mervos walk down Arthur Street as heavy rain floods the surrounding neighborhood on Wednesday, June 12, 2024, in Hollywood, Fla. (Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald via AP)\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). {"uri": "2024-06-388300727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:37:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:37:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T06:13:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://okcfox.com/news/nation-world/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days", "title": "Tropical disturbance brings flood crisis to southern Florida during hurricane season", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nRegardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. "dmoz/Recreation/Roads_and_Highways", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads and Highways", "wgt": 10}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads_and_Highways/North_America", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads and "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Natural_Disasters_and_Hazards", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Natural Disasters and Hazards", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "news/Environment", "label": "news/Environment", "wgt": 73}], "image": "https://okcfox.com/resources/media/e9d5ab44-e1ca-44c5-bd44-a9e41d1303d0-large16x9_AP24164723537089.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644091", "eventUri": "eng-9644091", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3019607843137255, "wgt": 214, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8175346651", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:03:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:03:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:02:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/06/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days - WTOP News", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather...\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. "dmoz/Recreation/Roads_and_Highways/North_America", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads and Highways/North America", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5154e3b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5333x2800+0+600/resize/1200x630!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnpr.brightspotcdn.com%2Fdims3%2Fdefault%2Fstrip%2Ffalse%2Fcrop%2F5333x4000%200%200%2Fresize%2F5333x4000%21%2F%3Furl%3Dhttp%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F4f%2F78%2Ff90ea6d74c848aa64f083aa07afa%2Fap24164723537089.jpg", {"uri": "2024-06-388741938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "18:41:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T18:41:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T20:41:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/nation-world/story/2024-06-12/floridas-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Dangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance has inundated much of southern Florida, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\n_____\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "8175219065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "02:54:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T02:54:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T02:53:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/article_d346b94f-f4d8-5185-99e0-768efc297d5d.html", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Not a subscriber? Buy a Day Pass or just this story using our new Digital Wallet\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@news-gazette.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "curt_anderson@news-gazette.com", "name": "Curt Anderson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_emergency", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Lauderdale,_Florida", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Fort Lauderdale, Florida"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Fort Lauderdale, Florida"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Florida"}, "location": {"uri": "2024-06-387925445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:51:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:51:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/13/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "Victor Corone, 66, pushes his wife Maria Diaz, 64, in a wheelchair through more than a foot of flood water on 84th street in Miami Beach, Fla. on Wednesday, June 12, 2024. The annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida, where a disorganized disturbance of tropical weather from the Gulf [...]\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source":
