{"uri": "2024-06-387871728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:37:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:37:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:31:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-043138023.html", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "Victor Corone, 66, pushes his wife Maria Diaz, 64, in a wheelchair through more than a foot of flood water on 84th street in Miami Beach, Fla. on Wednesday, June 12, 2024. The annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida, where a disorganized disturbance of tropical weather from the Gulf of Mexico has caused street flooding and triggered tornado watches but so far has not caused major damage or injuries. (AL Diaz/Miami Herald via AP)\n\nASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8175352025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:07:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:07:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:06:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/bb31b2d8ac01ee1300642ce674c6e61c/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-more", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "Mike Viesel and his dog Humi, wait in his flooded car for a tow truck after their car stalled out on Taft Street due to heavy rain flooding the neighborhood on Wednesday, June 12, 2024, in Hollywood, Fla. The annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida, where a disorganized disturbance of tropical weather from the Gulf of Mexico has caused street flooding and triggered tornado watches but so far has not caused major damage or injuries. (Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald via AP)\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "8175338652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:56:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:56:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:54:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13524851/After-rare-flash-flood-emergency-Florida-prepares-heavy-rainfall-coming-days.html", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy...", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nVictor Corone, 66, pushes his wife Maria Diaz, 64, in a wheelchair through more than a foot of flood water on 84th street in Miami Beach, Fla. on Wednesday, June 12, 2024. The annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida, where a disorganized disturbance of tropical weather from the Gulf of Mexico has caused street flooding and triggered tornado watches but so far has not caused major damage or injuries. (AL Diaz/Miami Herald via AP)\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties - Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I\u00b4d walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami\u00b4s Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can\u00b4t pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL\u00b4s Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nJim Comunale and Pam Mervos walk down Arthur Street as heavy rain floods the surrounding neighborhood on Wednesday, June 12, 2024, in Hollywood, Fla. {"uri": "8175561041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "07:48:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T07:48:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T07:47:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/06/13/nx-s1-5004450/florida-flash-flood-emergency-more-heavy-rain-coming", "title": "After a rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall", "body": "Victor Corone, 66, pushes his wife Maria Diaz, 64, in a wheelchair through more than a foot of floodwater in Miami Beach, Fla., on Wednesday, June 12, 2024. The annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida. Al Diaz/Miami Herald/AP hide caption\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches.\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "8176240401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:45:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://baynews9.com/fl/tampa/weather/2024/06/13/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency--florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days", "title": "Rare Flash Flood Emergency in South Florida on Wednesday", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) \u00e2\u20ac\" A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!,\u00e2\u20ac the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\u00e2\u20ac the service said on the social platform X. \u00e2\u20ac\u0153Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\u00e2\u20ac\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties \u00e2\u20ac\" Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122d walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \u00e2\u20ac\u0153has a problem with water.\u00e2\u20ac\n\nIn Miami\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153This is horrible. I can\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t pull my car around,\u00e2\u20ac he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153We are in trouble,\u00e2\u20ac McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "8175341596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:58:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:58:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:57:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/national/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/article_0e356f64-a077-5c0e-be51-3e11fb47da1e.html", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "Matthew Koziol, Mat\u00edas Ricci, Manuel Ricci and Ra\u00fal Fern\u00e1ndez travel by raft through a flooded street caused by heavy rain on North Bay Road in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla., Wednesday, June 12, 2024.\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8175418223", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "06:06:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T06:06:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T06:04:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://rsoe-edis.org/eventList/details/641146/0", "title": "Severe weather - United States - After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.Wednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.The disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.The disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.Numerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.The Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"Mayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.In nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.As he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"In Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.Dozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.Farther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.The winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.It's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).Bryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.More rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.The western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.Forecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.", "source": {"uri": "rsoe-edis.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "rsoe-edis.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This is horrible. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Natural_Disasters_and_Hazards", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Natural Disasters and Hazards", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Emergency_Preparation", "label": "dmoz/Home/Emergency Preparation", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "news/Environment", "label": "news/Environment", "wgt": 92}], "image": "https://www.manilatimes.net/manilatimes/uploads/images/2024/06/13/359211.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644091", "eventUri": "eng-9644091", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, {"uri": "2024-06-388441702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:37:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:37:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:32:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wpbf.com/article/florida-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/61095626", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Dangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.The disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.The disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.Numerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.The Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"Mayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.In nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.As he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"In Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.Dozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.Further north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.The winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.It's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).Bryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.More rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.The western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.Forecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.Fort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.Stay up-to-date: The latest headlines and weather from WPBF 25 Get the latest news updates with the WPBF 25 News app. You can download it here.\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\nStay up-to-date: The latest headlines and weather from WPBF 25", "source": {"uri": "wpbf.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WPBF"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8175331192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:49:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:49:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:46:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/13/nation/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-more-heavy-rainfall-coming-days/", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days - The Boston Globe", "body": "The disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "2024-06-387912116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:33:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:33:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:31:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/article_94eea318-a990-5948-b294-059397543013.html", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nMore from this section\n\n'The Trouble With Wolves' Brings Apex Predator's Plight to Documentary Showcase\n\nMCT Reports A 7% Mortgage Lock Volume Increase In Latest Indices Report\n\nLife in Full Bloom: Lutheran {"uri": "8175389462", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:39:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:39:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:39:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days-6034384.html", "title": "World News | After Rare Flash Flood Emergency, Florida Prepares for More Heavy Rainfall in Coming Days | LatestLY", "body": "Florida, Jun 13 (AP) A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nAlso Read | Kuwait Fire Tragedy: Around 40 Indians Killed, Says MEA; EAM S Jaishankar Speaks to His Kuwaiti Counterpart Abdullah Ali Al-Yahya.\n\nThe disorganised storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Centre.\n\nAlso Read | UFO Sighting in Canada: Barbell-Shaped UFO Glowing Indigo Blue Colour Spotted in Ontario, Claims Pentagon Engineer; Shares Electronic Evidence of 'Alien' Spacecraft.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane centre posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms. {"uri": "8176046231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "12:45:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T12:45:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T12:44:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/climate-and-environment/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days-1.6924909", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!,\" the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighbourhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or cancelled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimetres) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimetres) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimetres).\n\nBrian McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimetres) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimetres) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimetres) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Natural_Disasters_and_Hazards", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Natural Disasters and Hazards", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Emergency_Preparation", "label": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/content/dam/ctvnews/en/images/2024/6/13/florida-flooding-1-6924918-1718282227028.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644091", "eventUri": "eng-9644091",
