{"uri": "2024-06-388162300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:41:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:41:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:37:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.wgal.com/article/florida-heavy-rain-hurricane-season/61093204", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.Wednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.The disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.The disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.Numerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.The Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"Mayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.In nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.As he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"In Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.Dozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.Farther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.The winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.It's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches.Bryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.More rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.The western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.Forecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.___Associated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches.\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "wgal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGAL 8 Lancaster/Harrisburg"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8175339662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:56:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:56:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:55:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/after-rare-flash-flood-emergency-florida-prepares-for-more-heavy-rainfall-in-coming-days/article_05bfcdc6-6b39-5f7a-9454-34151bccc729.html", "title": "After rare flash flood emergency, Florida prepares for more heavy rainfall in coming days", "body": "An airplane is seen on the runway as heavy rain falls over the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport on Wednesday, June 12, 2024, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Many flights were either canceled or delayed due to the bad weather. (Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald via AP)\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "8176029404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "12:34:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T12:34:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T12:34:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/13/florida-flash-flood", "title": "Florida sees rare flash flood emergency with more heavy rain ahead: 'We are in trouble'", "body": "Downpours and flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed Florida Panthers on way to Stanley Cup games\n\nA tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!,\" the post said.\n\nNumerous roads remained flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward county, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the social platform X. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday the Florida governor, Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties - Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nDaniella Levine Cava, Miami-Dade county mayor, also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water\".\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about six inches (15cm) of rain fell Tuesday and seven inches (17cm) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about five inches (12cm).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some nine inches (23cm) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7am to 6pm on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another six inches (15cm) of rain.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644091", "eventUri": "eng-9644091", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1529411764705882, "wgt": 202, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8175032954", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "22:52:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T22:52:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T22:50:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/local/miami-dade/floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "Related I-95 southbound closed from Oakland Park Blvd to Griffin Road due to floodingFlorida's hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nFort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis declared a state of emergency late Wednesday afternoon.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" the mayor said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nJoin our Newsletter for the latest news right to your inbox Email address Submit", "source": {"uri": "wsvn.com", {"uri": "2024-06-387670429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:58:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:58:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T17:41:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/12/floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Victor Corone, 66, pushes his wife Maria Diaz, 64, in a wheelchair through more than a foot of flood water on 84th street in Miami Beach, Fla. on Wednesday, June 12, 2024. The annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida, where a disorganized disturbance of tropical weather from the Gulf [...]\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nFort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis declared a state of emergency late Wednesday afternoon.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" the mayor said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\n_____\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "8175147379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "01:23:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T01:23:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T01:22:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge-6034046.html", "title": "World News | Florida's 2024 Hurricane Season Arrives with a Rainy Deluge | LatestLY", "body": "Washington, Jun 13 (AP) Dangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganised storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nAlso Read | G7 Summit 2024: Joe Biden and Volodymyr Zelenskyy Will Sign Security Agreement Between US and Ukraine When They Meet at Group of Seven Summit.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nAlso Read | Kuwait Building Fire: Death Toll in Building Blaze Climbs to 49; PM Narendra Modi, EAM S Jaishankar Condole Deaths (Watch Videos).\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighbourhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or cancelled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimetres) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimetres) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimetres).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimeters) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 am to 6 pm on Wednesday in addition to the rain that fell on Tuesday.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" McNoldy wrote.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimetres) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85 per cent chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimetres) to 26 inches (66 centimetres). Many homes and businesses were flooded. {"uri": "2024-06-388675706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:18:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:18:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:07:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/stalled-cars-in-flooded-streets-leave-south-florida-looking-like-a-scene-from-a-zombie/article_399bb10c-63cc-501f-b121-816a978849c2.html", "title": "Stalled cars in flooded streets leave South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie", "body": "This arial view taken from video shows multiple cars stranded on a road in Northeast Miami-Dade County on Thursday, June 13, 2024. A tropical disturbance brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida the day before. Floridians prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9644091", "eventUri": "eng-9644091", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2013-06-", "textStart": 116, "textEnd": 123}], "sentiment": {"uri": "8176584912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:07:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:07:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:06:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/local/miami-dade/tropical-rainstorms-in-south-florida-lead-to-flight-delays-and-streets-jammed-with-stalled-cars/", "title": "Tropical rainstorms in South Florida lead to flight delays and streets jammed with stalled cars - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "Related South Florida storms cause public office closures; delays and cancellations at MIA, FLL, continueNorth Miami residents devastated by torrential downpours, forced from homesSouth Florida cities distribute sandbags to combat rising floodwatersParking fees waived in Broward, Miami-Dade cities amid floodingAs heavy rain pummels South Florida, tow truck drivers keep busy with stalled cars\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-388769960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:20:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:20:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:19:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.chiangraitimes.com/news/florida-prepares-for-more-heavy/", "title": "Florida Prepares For More Heavy Rainfall After A Flash Flood Emergency", "body": "(CTN News) - A tropical disturbance has caused a flash flood emergency throughout most of southern Florida. Residents anticipate heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nThe Florida Panthers' Stanley Cup game against the Edmonton Oilers in Canada was postponed Wednesday due to severe rain and floods.\n\nA disorganised storm system from the Gulf of Mexico was crossing Florida in early June, when hurricane season began. The year is expected to be one of the busiest due to climate change-related storm strength increases. The National Hurricane Centre says the disturbance has not grown into a cyclone and has a slim possibility of becoming a tropical system when it leaves Florida and enters the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe hurricane centre reported Wednesday that \"heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days, regardless of development.\n\nCars couldn't cross many flooded roads. The Florida Highway Patrol said in an email that personnel were pumping the drainage system and that southbound Interstate 95 in Broward County was being redirected to avoid a flooded portion.\n\nFlorida EPA says the road can't be reopened without draining the water.\n\nThe Miami weather service issued further alarming warnings. The service posted on X that \"the flooding that poses a threat to life is still present.\" \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nThe mayors of Hollywood and Fort Lauderdale declared emergencies on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis announced a state of emergency for Broward, Miami-Dade, Collier, Lee, and Sarasota counties on the Atlantic and west coasts, respectively.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava declared a local emergency. Hollywood neighbour Mike Viesel told the Miami Herald that he was caught in deep floodwater on a low-lying street on Wednesday afternoon while driving home with his dog Humi.\n\nAs he halted, Viesel stated oncoming cars poured additional water into his car. His engine stopped. \"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nAlfredo Rodriguez moved into a building in Miami's Edgewater section a year ago, and the lobby had pools of water on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\" I can't drive on Florida's flooded highways, he said.\n\nMany Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport flights were cancelled or delayed. It took over three hours for the NHL's Florida Panthers to travel from Fort Lauderdale to Edmonton for Stanley Cup Final Games 3 and 4. The trip was expected to take almost six hours.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound north of West Palm Beach on Florida's Atlantic Coast, according to the Melbourne National Weather Service.\n\nMartin County Fire Rescue said that the gusts downed many banyan trees and damaged a shop. The road damage on Rich Jupiter Island prevented access, but no injuries were reported.\n\nFlorida has had a wet and windy week. The National Weather Service reported 6 inches of rain in Miami and 7 inches in Miami Beach on Tuesday. Hollywood gained about five inches.\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, told X that South Florida received 9 inches of rain on Wednesday between 7 a.m. and 6 p.m. on top of Tuesday's downpour.\n\nMcNoldy responded, \"We are in trouble.\" The Miami meteorological service has extended the flash flood watch through Thursday due to expected rain throughout the week. Rain may increase by six inches in certain areas.\n\nThe western half of the state, which has been droughting, received a lot of rain. Weather service: Sarasota Bradenton International Airport received almost 6.5 inches of rain on Tuesday. Such places have flash flooding advisories.\n\nSEE ALSO:", "source": {"uri": "chiangraitimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTN News l Chiang Rai Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-387646683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:15:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:15:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/national/floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/article_1bc3ff78-0e32-55ec-ac3d-2c202a220036.html", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Dangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi in Hollywood, just south of Fort Lauderdale, when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but Humi \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8175672783", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:00:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:00:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T08:59:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/florida-braces-for-more-rain-after-rare-flash-flood-emergency/article68284168.ece", "title": "Florida braces for more rain after rare flash flood emergency", "body": "A tropical disturbance has brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida as residents prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on June 13 and 14.\n\nJune 12 downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nU.S. is starting to embrace cricket, says top American diplomat\n\nThe disorganised storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Centre.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane centre posted on its website on June 12.\n\nRecord 120 million people forcibly displaced globally: UNHCR\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\nFlood warnings across the region\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X , the social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\" Mayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on June 12 afternoon.\n\nLater on June 12, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Mrs Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nIn nearby Hollywood, Mr. Mike Viesel was driving home on June 12 afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Mr. Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Mr. Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nT20 World Cup: Nepal, Sri Lanka stare at exit after washout; South Africa make Super 8\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on June 12 morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, according to Martin County Fire Rescue officials. Although no injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimetres) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimetres) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimetres).\n\nBryan McNoldy, a senior research associate at the University of Miami Rosenstiel School, noted on X that some 9 inches (23 centimetres) had fallen on parts of South Florida from 7 a.m to 6 p.m. on June 12 in addition to the rain that fell on June 11.\n\n\"We are in trouble,\" Mr. McNoldy wrote.\n\nIncreasing incidence of hurricanes\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimetres) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimetres) of rain fell on June 11 at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hindu"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8176583214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:06:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:06:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:05:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-06-13/tropical-storm-flooding-south-florida-14171464.html", "title": "Tropical rainstorms in South Florida lead to flight delays and streets jammed with stalled cars", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "8174954059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:22:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:22:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:21:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://mynorthwest.com/3962448/floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Dangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi in Hollywood, just south of Fort Lauderdale, when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but his dog \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nIn Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Miami Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in.\n\n\"It was a surprise to me. I want to leave this place in the next three months. This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,\" he said of the flooded streets.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\n_____\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "mynorthwest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "My Northwest"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@mynorthwest.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_cyclone", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tropical cyclone"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida", "type": "loc",
