{"uri": "8174940399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:08:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:08:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:07:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.wral.com/story/floridas-hurricane-season-arrives-with-a-rainy-deluge/21478273/", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Dangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance inundated much of southern Florida on Wednesday, blocking roads, floating vehicles and delaying the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles. On major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County, southbound traffic was being diverted around a flooded section and contractors were on their way to pump the drainage system, the Florida Highway Patrol said in an email. The interstate wouldn't reopen until after water is drained, the agency said.\n\nThe Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the service said on the X social media platform. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nMike Viesel was driving home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi in Hollywood, just south of Fort Lauderdale, when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled.\n\n\"I'd walk out of my car,\" he told the Herald, but Humi \"has a problem with water.\"\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nFort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). Many homes and businesses were flooded.\n\n_____\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Freida Frisaro in Cooper City, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-388664474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:07:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:07:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T12:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/climate-and-environment/stalled-cars-in-flooded-streets-left-south-florida-looking-like-a-scene-from-a-zombie-movie-1.6924909", "title": "Stalled cars in flooded streets left South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie", "body": "A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravellers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nMatthew Koziol, Mat\u00edas Ricci, Manuel Ricci and Ra\u00fal Fern\u00e1ndez travel by raft through a flooded street caused by heavy rain on North Bay Road in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla., Wednesday, June 12, 2024. (David Santiago / Miami Herald via AP)\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nFrancisco Lopez stands near the flooded parking lot of his apartment building, Thursday, June 13, 2024, in Hallandale, Fla. (Marta Lavandier / AP Photo)\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "2024-06-388651771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:53:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:53:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:44:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/stalled-cars-in-flooded-streets-left-south-florida-looking-like-a-scene-from-a-zombie/article_399bb10c-63cc-501f-b121-816a978849c2.html", "title": "Stalled cars in flooded streets left South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8176325825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:44:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:44:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T15:42:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/florida-braces-more-rainfall-days-152615115.html", "title": "Florida braces for more rainfall after days of intense downpour and flash flooding", "body": "A slow-moving storm system infused with deep tropical moisture over South Florida will bring more very heavy rain and thunderstorms Thursday -- one day after flash flooding turned streets into rivers and triggered hundreds of flight delays and cancellations. Over a foot of rainfall was clocked in multiple areas.\n\nSeven million people remained under a flood watch Thursday across South Florida for what's forecast to be a third day of intense deluge.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the National Weather Service office in Miami warned on X.\n\nAs of Thursday morning, flood warnings were allowed to expire in parts of southern Florida, but residual flooding continues and several roads remain closed in hard hit areas. Heavy rain is forecast to pick up in the afternoon and evening hours\n\nThe National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center has issued a moderate risk of excessive rainfall through Friday morning.\n\nThe heavy rain will create \"numerous areas of flash flooding,\" the weather service said. \"Furthermore, many streams may flood, potentially affecting larger rivers.\"\n\nThe Miami metro area has practically zero tolerance for any more rain. Flash flood guidance reveals it'll take less than 0.25 inches of rain in just one hour to cause parts of the metro area to flood instantly.\n\nWednesday's downpour saw Gov. Ron DeSantis declare an emergency in Broward, Collier, Lee, Miami-Dade and Sarasota counties, allowing for state aid. The cities of Miami, Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood also issued emergency declarations.\n\nCars got stuck on inundated roads, water filled homes, locals were urged to stay in their residences, local airports saw hundreds of delays and cancellations, and part of the Interstate 95 in Broward County was closed to traffic for water to be drained.\n\nThe city of Aventura's police said that over 300 vehicles were towed off roadways and elderly individuals were rescued Wednesday from trapped vehicles.\n\nFort Lauderdale picked up 9.54 inches of rain in 24 hours, with Wednesday marking their wettest June day on record, and the third wettest calendar day on record.\n\nOverall, at least six weather stations from Miami to Fort Lauderdale picked up over 10 inches of rain -- the highest being 13.96 inches over Hialeah and 12.67 inches over the Hollywood/Hallandale Beach area. Most of the 10 to 12 inch rain totals came over the span of just five to six hours Wednesday.\n\nWhen combining Tuesday's rainfall, some locations across South Florida have picked up more than 20 inches of rain in just two days.\n\nThe more than a foot of rainfall that came down in just six hours over the Everglades reached the criteria for a 1-in-1,000-year event -- the second in just two days.\n\nOn Friday, the threat of excessive rainfall will decrease slightly over the southern tip of Florida, and a slight risk of excessive rainfall is in place for South Florida from Friday into Saturday morning.\n\nThrough Saturday morning, an additional 5 to 10 inches of rain will be possible including for the metro areas of Naples, Fort Myers, Miami, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach.", {"uri": "8176451585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:13:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:13:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:12:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/stalled-cars-in-flooded-streets-leave-south-florida-looking-like-a-scene-from-a-zombie/article_282e1534-4e03-5ea9-ab75-528a2eb11a55.html", "title": "Stalled cars in flooded streets leave South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-388788078", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:45:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:45:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:59:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tropical-rainstorms-in-south-florida-lead-to-flight-delays-and-streets-jammed-with-stalled-cars/article_94eea318-a990-5948-b294-059397543013.html", "title": "Tropical rainstorms in South Florida lead to flight delays and streets jammed with stalled cars", "body": "By FREIDA FRISARO, TERRY SPENCER and DANIEL KOZIN - Associated Press\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nMore from this {"uri": "8176487769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:44:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:44:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:42:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2024-06-13/stalled-cars-in-flooded-streets-leave-south-florida-looking-like-a-scene-from-a-zombie-movie", "title": "Stalled cars in flooded streets leave South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie", "body": "A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest-lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when it's coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches of rain have fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Va. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the [airport] employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early-June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches.\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "8176118689", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:29:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:29:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:28:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/weather/florida-braces-rainfall-days-intense-downpour-flash-flooding-rcna156936", "title": "Florida braces for more rainfall after days of intense downpour and flash flooding", "body": "Several areas in southern Florida picked up between 10 to 12 inches of rainfall Wednesday, with more on the way as seven million people remain under a flood watch.\n\nA slow-moving storm system infused with deep tropical moisture over southern Florida will bring more very heavy rain and thunderstorms on Thursday -- one day after flash flooding saw streets turned into rivers, triggered hundreds of flight delays and cancellations, and over a foot of rainfall was clocked in multiple areas.\n\nSeven million people remain under a flood watch across South Florida Thursday for what's forecast to be a third day of intense deluge.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the National Weather Service office in Miami warned on X.\n\nAs of Thursday morning, flood warnings were allowed to expire in parts of southern Florida, but residual flooding continues and several roads remain closed in hard hit areas. Heavy rain is forecast to pick up in the afternoon and evening hours\n\nThe National Weather Service's Weather Prediction Center has issued a moderate risk of excessive rainfall through Friday morning.\n\nThe heavy rain will create \"numerous areas of flash flooding,\" the weather service said. \"Furthermore, many streams may flood, potentially affecting larger rivers.\"\n\nThe Miami metro area has practically zero tolerance for any more rain. Flash flood guidance reveals it'll take less than 0.25 inches of rain in just one hour to cause parts of the metro area to flood instantly.\n\nYesterday's downpour saw Gov. Ron DeSantis declare an emergency in Broward, Collier, Lee, Miami-Dade and Sarasota counties, allowing for state aid. The cities of Miami, Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood also issued emergency declarations.\n\nCars got stuck on inundated roads, water filled homes, locals were urged to stay in their residences, local airports saw hundreds of delays and cancellations, and part of the Interstate 95 in Broward County was closed to traffic for water to be drained.\n\nThe City of Aventura's police said that over 300 vehicles were towed off roadways and elderly individuals were rescued Wednesday from trapped vehicles.\n\nFort Lauderdale picked up 9.54 inches of rain in 24 hours, with Wednesday marking their wettest June day on record, and the third wettest calendar day on record.\n\nOverall, at least six weather stations between Miami and Fort Lauderdale picked up over 10 inches of rain -- the highest being 13.96 inches over Hialeah and 12.67 inches over the Hollywood/Hallandale Beach area. Most of the 10 to 12 inch rain totals came over the span of just five to six hours Wednesday.\n\nWhen combining Tuesday's rainfall, some locations across south Florida have picked up more than 20 inches of rain in just two days.\n\nThe over foot of rainfall that came down in just six hours over the Everglades reached the criteria for a 1-in-1,000 year event -- the second to occur in just two days.\n\nOn Friday, the threat of excessive rainfall will decrease slightly over the southern tip of Florida, and a slight risk of excessive rainfall is in place for southern Florida from Friday into Saturday morning.\n\nThrough Saturday morning, an additional 5 to 10 inches of rain will be possible including for the metro areas of Naples, Fort Myers, Miami, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach.", days.\n\nOn Friday, the threat of excessive rainfall will decrease slightly over the southern tip of Florida, and a slight risk of excessive rainfall is in place for southern Florida from Friday into {"uri": "2024-06-388674375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:16:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:16:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:07:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/stalled-cars-in-flooded-streets-leave-south-florida-looking-like-a-scene-from-a-zombie/article_94eea318-a990-5948-b294-059397543013.html", "title": "Stalled cars in flooded streets leave South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie", "body": "By FREIDA FRISARO, TERRY SPENCER and DANIEL KOZIN - Associated Press\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, contributed to this story.\n\nMore from this Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for South Florida Wednesday evening after 24 hours of inclement weather brought heavy rain and flooding to the region.\n\nFlash flood warnings were issued for parts of Miami-Dade and Broward counties, where rainfall rates of several inches an hour submerged streets and snarled traffic.\n\nThe city of Sarasota was swamped Tuesday, with a record 3.93 inches of rain falling in just one hour. The rain forcing ground stops at both Miami International and Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International airports, causing delays in excess of seven hours.\n\n\"We were looking at renting a vehicle to try and make it even to Orlando and maybe get on a flight but that isn't going to work either,\" frustrated traveler Chris Stephens told CBS Miami.\n\nIn a statement, the governor's office said that the severe weather and flash flooding prompted DeSantis to declare state of emergencies for Broward, Collier, Lee, Miami-Dade and Sarasota counties.\n\nEarlier in the day, Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava and Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis also declared states of emergency, along with the cities of Dania Beach and Sunny Isles Beach.\n\n\"Due to ongoing heavy rainfall, several roadways throughout the City of Fort Lauderdale, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown are experiencing high water levels,\" Trantalis said on X.\n\nIn Dania Beach, there were at least 40 rescues conducted by police and fire crews, CBS News Miami learned.\n\nPeriods of heavy rain continued to flood low-lying areas, with poor drainage throughout South Florida.\n\nIn Lee County on the Gulf Coast, emergency officials had to rescue at least one driver from floodwaters. Farther north, a possible tornado brought down trees and powerlines in Martin County.\n\nThe storms are part of a stalled system that's pummeled Florida, dumping a month's worth of rain in just 24 hours, with more rain forecast this week.\n\nA flood advisory remained in effect for Miami-Dade and Broward counties through 10 p.m. The National Weather Service also issued a rare flash flood emergency for portions of southern Broward County and northern Miami-Dade which expired at 8 p.m.\n\nA flash flood warning was also issued for Broward and Miami-Dade.\n\nThe National Weather Service warned residents to \"move to higher ground now! This is an extremely dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.\"\n\nMeanwhile, officials at MIA said at least 221 flights had been canceled and 165 had been delayed so far Tuesday, while at FLL there were at least 261 flight cancelations and 166 delays.\n\nThe Florida Panthers were on a three-hour delay at FLL before their flight took off to Edmonton, Canada, for Game 3 of their Stanley Cup Final series.\n\nSouth Florida officials said pump trucks were either in place or headed to flooded areas where they are needed.\n\nIn Broward County, part of I-95 had been closed due to flooding on the highway.\n\nPower outages were also reported across South Florida, and some traffic lights had been affected, making an already dire driving situation even worse for drivers.\n\nFlorida Power & Light said there were more than 8,900 customers without power in Miami-Dade County as of Tuesday evening, and another approximately 1,900 without power in Broward County.\n\nLaw enforcement was warning drivers in need of a tow to call tow truck companies first if possible, as opposed to immediately contacting police.\n\nThis wet, stormy weather pattern will hold in South Florida through the end of the work week, forecasters say, with the tropical moisture dissipating slightly by the weekend. That will leave the region a bit drier, but there will still be a chance for storms, but not nearly as widespread.\n\nOver the past 24 hours, Miami Beach saw nearly 7 inches of rain, Hallandale Beach saw 6 inches of rain, while Hollywood, North Miami and Coral Gables received just over 5 inches.\n\nThe 4 to 6 inches of rain that fell Tuesday squashed the rainfall deficit in Miami-Dade County, and {"uri": "8175898631", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:16:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:16:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T11:14:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13525933/Devastating-dangerous-rainfall-flooding-swamp-streets-Florida.html", "title": "Devastating dangerous rainfall and flooding swamp streets in Florida", "body": "Dangerous, heavy rainfall has swamped the streets of Florida as a tropical disturbance brings a rare flash flood emergency to much of the state. Devastating downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and left dozens of drivers stranded Wednesday in a storm that some residents have said is unlike anything they have ever experienced before.\n\nThe storm turned several roads in south Florida into rivers and lakes, forcing locals to abandoned their cars and wade through the water. Interstate 95 reopened early this morning after the Florida Highway Patrol closed parts closed parts of the major artery on Wednesday after it became impassable for drivers. Governor Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency for five counties as residents prepare to weather more heavy rainfall today and tomorrow, which forecasters warn could trigger flash floods in central and south Florida.\n\nA tropical disturbance will continue to unleash torrential downpours across Florida today, bringing a rare flash flood emergency to much of the state. The disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season - which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity. The disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center. 'Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,' the hurricane center said.\n\nForecasters predict between 18 and 24 inches of rain will fall across southwestern Florida throughout the course of the storm. Some radar suggests the region could see up to 30 inches of rainfall, which is typical of a severe slow-moving tropical storm or hurricane. AccuWeather Meteorologist Bernie Rayno warned that the storm will be 'like a wall of water coming at southern and central Florida into Thursday'. 'The steadiest and heaviest rain will fall on South and central Florida through Thursday, but more spotty downpours and thunderstorms will continue to pester the region into Saturday,' added AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Rene\u00e9 Duff.\n\nFlorida had been battling extreme heat and drought conditions prior to the arrival of Tuesday's tropical rainstorm. But as of Wednesday afternoon more than 11 inches of rain had already fallen across communities in the southwestern region of the state, with Fort Myers recording more than 5 inches. Forecasters warn that for much of central and south Florida, the rainfall over the next few days could approach or exceed the total amount of rain that fell in the first five months of the year. Several roadways were underwater Wednesday night after a tropical storm caused major flooding, flooding blocked roads and floated vehicles.\n\nDozens of drivers were forced to abandoned their vehicles along Hollywood Boulevard in Hollywood, located between Fort Lauderdale and Miami, as water kept rising. 'I got stuck with this car, if that car would move I would move too,' one driver told NBC Miami. 'I feel so bad, so terrible, this has never happened to me in my life.' Another added: 'I've never seen this in my life.' Mike Viesel was driving to his Hollywood home Wednesday afternoon with his dog Humi when he was caught in deep floodwater along a low-lying street, he told the Miami Herald.\n\nAs he slowed down and stopped, Viesel said other cars drove past him, sending even more water into his vehicle. His engine stalled. 'I'd walk out of my car,' he told the Herald, but his dog 'has a problem with water.' In Miami's Edgewater neighborhood, the lobby of the building that Alfredo Rodriguez moved into a year ago already had water puddles inside on Wednesday morning. He told the Herald the building has flooded five times since he moved in. 'This is horrible. I can't pull my car around,' he said of the flooded streets.\n\nNumerous roads were impassable for vehicles on Wednesday, including Interstate 95 in Broward County. Highway patrol was forced to divert southbound traffic around a flooded section of the interstate as contractors worked to pump the drainage system. The interstate, which officials have warned would remain closed until the water was drained, reopened early Thursday morning.\n\nDozens of flights were delayed or canceled at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport on Wednesday. The NHL's Florida Panthers were delayed more than three hours from departing Fort Lauderdale for their nearly six-hour flight to Edmonton for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup Final. The Miami weather service office issued increasingly dire warnings on Wednesday, as the storm system worsened. 'Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,' the service said on the X social media platform. 'Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.' Mayors in Fort Lauderdale, Hollywood and Miami-Dade County declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nLater Wednesday, Gov. DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties - Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast. Farther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning. The winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road. More rain is forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through today.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well. Forecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85 per cent chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average , predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? {"uri": "8176607063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:28:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:28:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:26:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/tropical-rainstorms-in-south-florida-lead-to-flight-delays-and-streets-jammed-with-stalled-cars/article_05bfcdc6-6b39-5f7a-9454-34151bccc729.html", "title": "Tropical rainstorms in South Florida lead to flight delays and streets jammed with stalled cars", "body": "FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kinda par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami noted in a post on the social media platform X early Thursday that a band of heavy rainfall was expected to fall over the region for a third day in a row.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Even a small duration of heavy rainfall could lead to more flash flooding!\" the post said.\n\nMayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared a state of emergency for their cities on Wednesday afternoon. Later Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis also declared a state of emergency for five counties -- Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast and Collier, Lee and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also issued a local state of emergency.\n\nFarther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed that an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe winds knocked down multiple banyan trees and caused some damage to a store, Martin County Fire Rescue officials said. No injuries were reported, but access to wealthy Jupiter Island was cut off by debris on the road.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press sports writer Stephen Whyno in Edmonton, Canada, and Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg, Florida, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "8174795200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "18:53:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T18:53:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T18:50:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/a37631902e119c0036d1fd51da2dba15/floridas-2024-hurricane-season-arrives-rainy-deluge", "title": "Florida's 2024 hurricane season arrives with a rainy deluge", "body": "Laura Collinhofer holds an umbrella after moving her cars to higher ground as heavy rain falls over parts of South Florida on Wednesday, June 12, 2024, in Hollywood, Fla. (Matias J. Ocner/Miami Herald via AP)\n\nThe annual rainy season has arrived with a wallop in much of Florida, where a disorganized disturbance of tropical weather from the Gulf of Mexico has caused street flooding and triggered tornado watches but so far has not caused major damage or injuries.\n\nFlorida's rainy season roughly begins in June with the start of the six-month hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory. The disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it emerges into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the hurricane center posted on its website Wednesday.\n\nNumerous roads were flooded and impassable for vehicles, including a section of major artery Interstate 95 in Broward County. The Florida Highway Patrol said southbound traffic was being diverted around the flooded section.\n\n\"This closure will remain until further notice and water drains from the interstate. Contractors are enroute to pump the drainage system,\" FHP said in an email.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida, especially in the Miami and Fort Lauderdale areas. In Miami about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood, just south of Fort Lauderdale, got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, leading the weather service office in Miami to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday. Some places could see another half-foot (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. In Sarasota, nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nThe deluge comes amid forecasts of an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. {"uri": "8175489024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "06:59:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T06:59:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T06:58:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/state-emergency-declared-florida-counties-heavy-rain-leads-severe-flooding-3734289", "title": "DeSantis Declares State Of Emergency After Florida Flooding", "body": "Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency in five counties Wednesday following severe flooding caused by a tropical disturbance. The deluge battered southern Florida, blocking roads, stranding vehicles, forcing flight delays and cancellations at airports.\n\nThe disorganized storm system, moving across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico, coincided with the early June start of hurricane season. This year's hurricane season is expected to be one of the most active in recent history, according to Associated Press.\n\nAlthough the disturbance has not yet reached cyclone status, the National Hurricane Center indicated only a slight chance of it developing into a tropical system once it crosses Florida and moves into the Atlantic Ocean.\n\nThe flooding made several roads impassable in Florida, including a section of Interstate 95 in Broward County, where southbound traffic was being diverted. Contractors were dispatched to pump the drainage system, while the Florida Highway Patrol confirmed that the interstate would remain closed until the water was drained.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Miami office issued increasingly urgent warnings. \"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing. Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground,\" it posted on X.\n\nIn response to the flooding, mayors in Fort Lauderdale and Hollywood declared states of emergency in their cities. DeSantis extended it to include Broward and Miami-Dade on Florida's Atlantic coast, as well as Collier, Lee, and Sarasota counties on the state's west coast. Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also declared a local state of emergency.\n\nFort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis reported significant flooding in the city, including major thoroughfares like Broward Boulevard and Federal Highway near downtown.\n\nThe flooding also disrupted operations at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, causing numerous flight delays and cancellations. The NHL's Florida Panthers experienced a more than three-hour delay departing Fort Lauderdale for Edmonton for the Stanley Cup Final games.\n\nFurther north, the National Weather Service in Melbourne confirmed an EF-1 tornado hit Hobe Sound on Florida's Atlantic Coast north of West Palm Beach Wednesday morning.\n\nForecasters have predicted more rain throughout the week, prompting the Miami weather service office to extend a flash flood watch through Thursday.\n\nSome areas could receive an additional 6 inches of rain. The western side of the state, which has been experiencing a prolonged drought, also saw significant rainfall, with nearly 6.5 inches recorded at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport on Tuesday. {"uri": "8176664542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "20:26:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T20:26:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T20:23:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/tropical-rainstorms-in-south-florida-lead-to-flight-delays-and-streets-jammed-with-stalled-cars/article_8bf04d27-c5e2-5c2e-be5e-8542e5c87f57.html", "title": "Tropical rainstorms in South Florida lead to flight delays and streets jammed with stalled cars", "body": "This aerial view taken from video shows multiple cars stranded on a road in Northeast Miami-Dade County, Fla., on Thursday, June 13, 2024. A tropical disturbance brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida the day before. Floridians prepared to weather more heavy rainfall on Thursday and Friday.\n\nFORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) -- A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest-lying streets.\n\n\"Looked like the beginning of a zombie movie,\" said Ted Rico, a tow truck driver who spent much of Wednesday night and Thursday morning helping to clear the streets of stalled vehicles. \"There's cars littered everywhere, on top of sidewalks, in the median, in the middle of the street, no lights on. Just craziness, you know. Abandoned cars everywhere.\"\n\nRico, of One Master Trucking Corp., was born and raised in Miami and said he was ready for the emergency.\n\n\"You know when its coming,\" he said. \"Every year it's just getting worse, and for some reason people just keep going through the puddles.\"\n\nTravelers across the area were trying to adjust their plans on Thursday morning. More than 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain has fallen in some areas of South Florida since Tuesday, with more predicted over the next few days.\n\nTicket and security lines snaked around a domestic concourse at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport just before noon Thursday. The travel boards showed about half of that terminal's flights had been canceled or postponed.\n\nBill Carlisle, a Navy petty officer first class, had spent his morning trying to catch a flight back to Norfolk, Virginia. He had arrived at Miami International Airport at about 6:30 a.m., but 90 minutes later he was still in line and realized he couldn't get his bags checked and through security in time to catch his flight.\n\n\"It was a zoo,\" said Carlisle, a public affairs specialist. He was speaking for himself, not the Navy. \"Nothing against the (airport) employees -- there is only so much they can do.\"\n\nSo he used his phone to book an afternoon flight out of Fort Lauderdale. He took a shuttle the 20 miles north, only to find that flight had been canceled. He was now heading back to Miami for a 9 p.m. flight, hoping it wouldn't get canceled by the heavy rains expected later in the day. He was resigned, not angry.\n\n\"Just a long day sitting in airports,\" Carlisle said. \"This is kind of par for the course for government travel.\"\n\nWednesday's downpours and subsequent flooding blocked roads, floated vehicles and even delayed the Florida Panthers on their way to Stanley Cup games in Canada against the Edmonton Oilers.\n\nThe disorganized storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the early June start of hurricane season, which this year is forecast to be among the most active in recent memory amid concerns that climate change is increasing storm intensity.\n\nThe disturbance has not reached cyclone status and was given only a slight chance to form into a tropical system once it moves into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida, according to the National Hurricane Center.\n\nIn Hallandale Beach, Alex Demchemko, was walking his Russian spaniel Lex along the still-flooded sidewalks near the Airbnb where he's lived after arriving from Russia last month to seek asylum in the U.S.\n\n\"We didn't come out from our apartment, but we had to walk with our dog,\" Demchemko said. \"A lot of flashes, raining, a lot of floating cars and a lot of left cars without drivers, and there was a lot of water on the streets. It was kind of catastrophic.\"\n\nOn Thursday morning, Daniela Urrieche, 26, was bailing water out of her SUV, which got stuck on a flooded street as she drove home from work on Wednesday afternoon.\n\n\"In the nine years that I've lived here, this has been the worst,\" she said. \"Even in a hurricane, streets were not as bad as it was in the past 24 hours.\"\n\nThe flooding wasn't limited to the streets. Charlea Johnson spent Wednesday night at her Hallendale Beach home barreling water into the sink and toilet.\n\n\"The water just started flooding in the back and flooding in the front,\" Johnson said.\n\nBy Wednesday evening, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, and mayors in Fort Lauderdale , Hollywood and Miami-Dade County each declared a state of emergency.\n\nIt's already been a wet and blustery week in Florida. In Miami, about 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday and 7 inches (17 centimeters) fell in Miami Beach, according to the National Weather Service. Hollywood got about 5 inches (12 centimeters).\n\nMore rain was forecast for the rest of the week, with some areas getting another 6 inches (15 centimeters) of rain.\n\nThe western side of the state, much of which has been in a prolonged drought, also got some major rainfall. Nearly 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain fell Tuesday at Sarasota Bradenton International Airport, the weather service says, and flash flood warnings were in effect in those areas as well.\n\nForecasts predict an unusually busy hurricane season.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there is an 85% chance that the Atlantic hurricane season will be above average, predicting between 17 and 25 named storms in the coming months including up to 13 hurricanes and four major hurricanes. An average season has 14 named storms.\n\nAssociated Press writers Curt Anderson in St. Petersburg and Stephany Matat, in Hallandale Beach, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri":
