{"uri": "2024-06-388628062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:26:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:26:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:17:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article289242435.html", "title": "With 20 inches of rain, South Florida is swamped. Was it worse than last year?", "body": "The deluge that swamped parts of South Florida this week was extraordinary, but not as bad as what the region saw about a year ago when even more rain hit Fort Lauderdale, according to records kept by a federal weather agency.\n\n\"I've already heard a little bit of people trying to make comparisons to the rainfall amounts,\" said Robert Molleda, a forecaster with the National Weather Service's Miami office. \"Those rainfall amounts that they saw in Fort Lauderdale [last year] were much higher, and they occurred over a much shorter period of time.\"\n\nWhile parts of southeastern Broward and northeastern Miami-Dade saw 20 inches of rain this week over 48 hours, Molleda said in that April 2023, the Fort Lauderdale area got hit with about two feet of rain over a single 24-hour period -- with 20 inches falling in less than 12 hours.\n\nThe 2023 deluge disrupted fuel operations in Port Everglades, leading to gas shortages across the region, closed schools for multiple days and had residents escaping homes through windows. Last year's flooding accompanied the rainiest day in Fort Lauderdale since records were kept, with 22.5 inches falling on April 12, 2023, according to a rainfall summary maintained by the National Weather Service.\n\nRainfall records get measured in different ways, including high points for a particular day and precipitation measured at individual rain stations over 24-hour periods.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday's 9.5 inches in Fort Lauderdale was the most for a June day and broke a daily record of 5.47 inches on June 12 that had stood since 1978. It also broke the overall June record of 8.6 inches set in 1930.\n\nMolleda said this week's rain fell hard enough and quickly enough to overwhelm drainage systems, swamp roads and generally lead to far more disruption than the typical summer downpour.\n\n\"It's not really about the amounts. It's about where the rainfall occurs and that area's ability to handle that amount of rainfall,\" he said during a Thursday press conference held by Miami-Dade County at its Doral emergency operations center. \"For example, yesterday we saw about 10 inches in about five hours. That's enough -- more than enough -- in those areas to cause flooding.\"", "source": {"uri": "miamiherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Miami Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-388518610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:44:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:44:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-06-13/south-florida-braced-for-life-threatening-flooding-after-a-foot-of-rain", "title": "South Florida Braced for 'Life-Threatening' Flooding After a Foot of Rain", "body": "(Reuters) - More torrential downpours fell over South Florida on Thursday after at least a foot of rain deluged an area spanning the Gulf Coast into Miami this week, leading the National Weather Service to issue flood watches or warnings for 8 million people.\n\nSome areas, including portions of Broward and Miami-Dade counties, are seeing \"life-threatening flooding,\" the weather service said.\n\nA few spots have reported up to 18-to-25 inches of rain since Monday, said Bob Oravec, a forecaster with the NWS's Weather Prediction Center in College Park, Maryland.\n\nThe slow-moving storm - a disorganized tropical depression drawing its strength from warm Gulf Coast and Atlantic waters - is expected to linger over the state until early Saturday before pushing out to sea, Oravec said.\n\nEven though the system is not expected to turn into a tropical storm, it could be a wet prelude to what is expected to be a busy hurricane season, which began June 1.\n\nWith another 5 inches of rain possible before Friday night, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for five South Florida Counties late on Wednesday.\n\nMedia reports and social media posts showed cars stalled and people wading in hip-deep waters flooding streets. Parts of Interstate 95, a main north-south route along the East Coast, were closed due to flooding on Wednesday.\n\n\"The problem is that there is no place for the rain to go,\" said Oravec. \"The ground is so saturated. In some places water is rising up from the sewers.\"\n\nFort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis declared a city-wide emergency due to flooding. He said the Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission was sending boats and high-water vehicles to assist any rescues if needed.\n\nTrantalis urged people to stay off roadways. \"It's crucial to never attempt to drive through high water,\" he warned in a message on the X social media platform.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also declared states of emergency, freeing up money and resources to better cope with the storm and its aftermath.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta; Editing by Frank McGurty, Kirsten Donovan)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8176420026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:50:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:50:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:48:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2982020-florida-faces-torrential-downpours-and-life-threatening-flooding", "title": "Florida Faces Torrential Downpours and Life-Threatening Flooding | Science-Environment", "body": "Torrential downpours continue to batter South Florida, leading to flood warnings for 8 million residents. Some areas have reported up to 25 inches of rain since Monday. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency. Forecasters anticipate this could be a prelude to a busy hurricane season.\n\nMore torrential downpours deluged South Florida on Thursday, adding to more than a foot of rain that fell on parts of the state this week and leading forecasters to issue flood watches or warnings for an area where 8 million people reside. Some areas, including portions of Broward and Miami-Dade counties, are threatened with \"life-threatening flooding,\" the National Weather Service said.\n\nA few spots have reported up to 18-to-25 inches of rain since Monday, said Bob Oravec, a forecaster with the service's Weather Prediction Center in College Park, Maryland. The slow-moving storm - a disorganized tropical depression drawing its strength from warm Gulf Coast and Atlantic waters - is expected to linger over the state until early Saturday before pushing out to sea, Oravec said.\n\nEven though the system is not expected to strengthen into a tropical storm, it could be a wet prelude to what is expected to be a busy hurricane season, which got underway on June 1. With another 5 inches of rain possible before Friday night, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for five South Florida Counties late on Wednesday.\n\nMedia reports and social media posts showed stalled cars and people wading in streets covered in hip-deep water, or paddling in small boats and kayaks. In some areas water has swamped lawns and pushed up to the front doors of houses and other buildings. Parts of Interstate 95, a main north-south route along the East Coast, were closed due to flooding on Wednesday.\n\n\"The problem is that there is no place for the rain to go,\" said Oravec. \"The ground is so saturated. In some places water is rising up from the sewers.\" The storm led officials to postpone the demolition of the building at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida where 17 students and staff were killed in February 2018 in one of the worst mass shootings in U.S. history.\n\nThe building, some parts still bloodstained, was closed immediately after the shooting and fenced off to preserve evidence. The demolition has been rescheduled for Friday. In nearby Fort Lauderdale, Mayor Dean Trantalis declared a city-wide emergency due to flooding. He said the Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission was sending boats and high-water vehicles to assist any rescues if needed.\n\nTrantalis urged people to stay off roadways. \"It's crucial to never attempt to drive through high water,\" he warned in a message on the X social media platform. Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also declared states of emergency, freeing up money and resources to better cope with the storm and its aftermath.\n\nHURRICANE FORECAST Forecasters are expecting eight to 13 hurricanes in the Atlantic this season, seven of which could build into major storms. Overall some 17 to 25 named tropical storms are expected.\n\nAn average hurricane season produces about 14 named storms, of which seven become hurricanes. In recent years, the frequency and intensity of hurricanes has increased linked to warming sea temperatures caused by higher carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.\n\n(This story has not been edited Miami is about even with the June average of 10.51.\"\n\nThe current weather alerts in effect as of 8AM this morning are Flood Watches. They have been extended through Friday evening for Miami-Dade and Broward for an additional 4-8 inches of rain and through Friday morning for the Florida Keys for up to 2-4 inches of rain.\n\nIt won't take much additional rain to cause or worsen flooding given how saturated the grounds are, especially where flooding remains in place.\n\nThere is also the isolated severe storm risk, including the threats of a tornado and damaging winds.\n\nThe next round of rain and storms that will lead to these flood and severe weather concerns will begin to move in midday today around lunchtime and will persist through much of the afternoon. {"uri": "8174062352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "10:38:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T10:38:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T10:38:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/local/miami-dade/heavy-rainfall-brings-flooding-to-miami-dade-and-broward/", "title": "Heavy rainfall brings flooding to Miami-Dade and Broward - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "(WSVN) - The National Weather Service has extended a flood watch through Thursday evening as South Florida braces for continued heavy rainfall, which began on Tuesday and is expected to persist throughout the week.\n\nCommunities in Miami-Dade and Broward counties are particularly affected by floodwaters that have already reached significant levels. Since midnight, Miami Beach has recorded 6.95 inches of rainfall, while Hallandale has seen 6.01 inches. Other notable totals include 5.02 inches in Miami Shores, 4.41 inches in North Miami, and 3.82 inches in Hollywood.\n\nThe relentless downpour has put immense pressure on the drainage systems.\n\nIn Miami, floodwaters surged through Brickell Avenue and Southeast 14th Street, causing cars to create large wakes. The rushing water flowed down South Miami Avenue, affecting businesses such as Paperfish and Sexy Fish, with sidewalks submerged.\n\nA manhole cover was pushed up by the force of the water on Brickell Bay Drive, and another near the Brightline station in Downtown Miami experienced similar issues.\n\n\"Some of the flooding is pretty crazy. I'm not gonna lie,\" said Ethan, a local resident caught in the rain with friends, who chose to brave the weather for an unusual evening activity.\n\nIn Miami Beach, the streets were heavily flooded, with areas like 71st Street, Harding Avenue, Alton Road, and 46th Street becoming impassable. One resident described seeing Corvettes almost underwater, estimating thousands of dollars in damage.\n\nBusinesses in Miami Beach are facing significant cleanup costs as floodwaters continue to seep in. Sheets of rain have reduced visibility from high-rises and slowed traffic on Interstate 95 near the 836 interchange, despite pumps working in overdrive to manage the water.\n\n\"It's a little annoying, but I mean, we will deal with it,\" another resident commented on the ongoing challenges.\n\nIn Hallandale, six inches of rain on Tuesday led to the temporary closure of Hallandale Beach Boulevard due to severe flooding. Although the avenue has since reopened, the forecast suggests more rain is on the way for South Florida residents.\n\nCommunities across South Florida are experiencing similar conditions. In Surfside, water gushed into a residential parking garage on 92nd Street and Collins Avenue.\n\nOpa-locka saw residential streets flooded, with even a Brinks truck struggling through deep puddles. Hialeah's mobile home community on West 29th Street was inundated, and residents had to navigate significant flooding.\n\nDania Beach and Hollywood also reported heavy flooding, with rain pouring down on the Turnpike and causing traffic issues on I-95 during rush hour.\n\nBroward County officials have proactively prepared for the continued rainfall by clearing debris from storm drains to facilitate water flow.\n\n\"We know this whole week and probably on through next week, based on the forecast, we're going to experience a lot of rain,\" one official stated.\n\nTeams have been dispatched to flood-prone locations to mitigate the impact.\n\nAs South Florida continues to cope with the adverse weather, residents are urged to stay safe and remain informed about the inclement weather.\n\nCopyright 2024 Sunbeam Television Corp. Earlier in the day, Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava and Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis also declared states of emergency, along with the cities of Dania Beach and Sunny Isles Beach. In Dania Beach, there were at least 40 rescues conducted by police and fire crews.\n\nOn Thursday, all Broward County public schools are closed for summer sessions. Also closed are county courts, U.S. district courts, and Dania Beach's city hall. The city's Clerk's Office remains open for election-related business.\n\nMiami-Dade public schools will be open for the summer session.\n\nFlorida International University's Biscayne Bay campus and the campus at I-75 are closed due to flooding. Nova Southeastern University's Oceanographic Center is also closed Thursday due to flooding.\n\nDue to flooding conditions on sections of the railroad, Tri-Rail service between Metrorail Transfer and MiamiCentral stations remains suspended Thursday morning. Passengers are advised to use the Metrorail system.\n\nSeveral South Florida cities have received more than 15 inches of rain in the last two days.\n\nNorth Miami has received more than 20 inches, Hallandale Beach and Hollywood have received more than 19 inches, Davie has gotten nearly 18 inches, Dania Beach 10 inches, and Plantation nearly nine inches.\n\nA flood warning is in effect for much of Miami-Dade and Broward through 8 a.m. Thursday. A flood watch is in effect through Friday at 8 p.m.\n\nSome locations that will experience flooding include Miami, Hialeah, Fort Lauderdale, Pembroke Pines, Hollywood, Miramar, Pompano Beach, Davie, Miami Beach, Plantation, Sunrise, Tamarac, Margate, Coral Gables, Key Biscayne, South Miami, Lauderdale-By-The-Sea, Surfside, Miami Gardens and Hallandale Beach, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nThe wet, stormy weather pattern will hold in South Florida through the end of the work week, forecasters say, with the tropical moisture dissipating slightly by the weekend. {"uri": "8174199679", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "12:02:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T12:02:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T12:01:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/southern-florida-receives-record-rainfall-flash-flooding-500-1000-year-rcna156700", "title": "Southern Florida receives record rainfall and flash flooding in a 500-to-1,000-year event", "body": "The 3.93 inches of rain that fell at the Sarasota-Bradenton Airport in one hour is also a record -- and more rain is expected this week.\n\nA city on Florida's west coast was hit by a record-breaking 8 inches of rain in just three hours on Tuesday evening, bringing flash floods to the area, hindering drivers and delaying hundreds of flights across the state.\n\nSo rare was Tuesday's rain between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. in Sarasota that it should only be expected every 500 to 1,000 years. The Tampa Bay area can normally expect 7.3 inches in the entire month of June.\n\nThe 3.93 inches of rain that fell at the Sarasota-Bradenton Airport airport in one hour is also a record.\n\nCoastal areas in Sarasota County saw up to 10 inches of rain on Tuesday alone, with the same possible Wednesday and throughout the week, the NWS office in Tampa Bay said.\n\nVideo uploaded to social media showed a fire truck and lanes of traffic driving badly flooded roads in Sarasota. Across the region cars became stranded after attempting to drive through deep water, including in Siesta Key to the west of Sarasota.\n\nThe weather system was caused by deep tropical moisture from a disturbance called 90-L by the National Hurricane Center, as well as a small area of low pressure of Florida's west coast and \"a very slow-moving stubborn convergent band,\" according to Jeff Berardelli, chief meteorologist at NBC affiliate WFLA of Tampa.\n\nMore rain is expected throughout this week across the state. The National Weather Service warned residents to expect more than 7 inches of rain in \"a prolonged heavy to excessive rainfall event across southern Florida for the next several days,\" in a forecast early Wednesday.\n\nThe rain comes after parts of Florida have spent many months in a drought. Sarasota has received 25 inches less rain than it normally would since the start of 2023, which was its driest on record.\n\nThe area's extremely dry soil has in part helped to limit flooding, as the soil could absorb more rain then normal, Berardelli wrote.\n\nMiami International Airport reported 462 delays and 52 cancellations, while Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport had 331 delays {"uri": "8175273840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "03:52:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T03:52:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T03:51:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/desantis-declares-state-of-emergency-for-south-florida-flooding-5667940", "title": "DeSantis Declares State of Emergency for South Florida Flooding", "body": "Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency in five counties on Wednesday following severe flooding and rainfall across southern Florida.\n\nDangerous flooding from a tropical disturbance dubbed Invest 90L by the National Hurricane Center (NHC) inundated much of the state, blocking roads and floating vehicles. An invest is a naming convention used during hurricane season.\n\n\"I have declared a state of emergency for Broward, Collier, Lee, Miami-Dade, and Sarasota counties due to major flooding from Invest 90L,\" Mr. DeSantis wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nInvest 90L swept across the Florida Peninsula in the early hours of June 11. According to the order, the weather system brought 10 to 15 inches of rain, impacting critical infrastructure such as major interstates, state and county roadways, airports, and schools.\n\nThe Miami branch of the NWS issued strong warnings to residents on Wednesday on X.\n\n\"Life-threatening flooding is now ongoing,\" the agency said. \"Please stay off the roadways and get to higher ground.\"\n\nAt the time of publishing, the NHC's latest outlook reported that an elongated area of low pressure currently over the Florida Peninsula is producing a large area of disorganized showers and thunderstorms.\n\nThe storm system was pushing across Florida from the Gulf of Mexico at roughly the same time as the start of hurricane season in early June.\n\nThe weather system hasn't formed into a cyclone at this stage. The NHC reported that there was only a slight chance that it may form into a tropical system once it pushes into the Atlantic Ocean after crossing Florida.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is forecast to continue across portions of the Florida peninsula during the next few days,\" the NHC reported on Wednesday.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Miami issued a warning of \"life-threatening flooding\" in the area on Wednesday afternoon. Residents were advised to seek higher ground, and drivers were urged to get off the roads.\n\nTo manage the emergency response, Mr. DeSantis appointed Kevin Guthrie, the director of the Division of Emergency Management, to coordinate the state's response.\n\nThe declaration also authorizes the activation of the Florida National Guard and the Florida State Guard to aid in emergency response efforts.\n\nAccording to the executive order, state agencies have the authority to suspend regulatory statutes and rules that might impede necessary actions to address the crisis.\n\nThe Florida Division of Emergency Management has actively deployed requested resources to impacted communities, it announced on X.\n\n\"It's never safe to enter floodwaters -- and they're especially dangerous at night. Turn around, don't drown! Listen to all orders from local officials and have multiple ways to receive emergency alerts,\" it said.\n\nThe executive order also allows medical professionals with valid licenses from other states to provide free services in Florida during the emergency, under the auspices of the American Red Cross or the Florida Department of Health.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", The highest totals are expected near Everglades City at up to 12 inches of rain.\n\nThe weather service warned that higher totals, near 15 inches, cannot be ruled out along the Gulf Coast.\n\nAs of Monday morning, it appeared Wednesday could be the rainiest day.\n\nIn response to the rain worries, the South Florida Water Management District warned of a strong potential for flooding in low-lying and poorly draining spots, particularly along the coast.\n\n\"Over the next five days, rainfall is expected to be significantly above average for this time of year,\" the district warned.\n\nThe Earlier in the day, Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava and Fort Lauderdale Mayor Dean Trantalis also declared states of emergency, along with the cities of Dania Beach and Sunny Isles Beach. In Dania Beach, there were at least 40 rescues conducted by police and fire crews.\n\nOn Thursday, all Broward County public schools are closed for summer sessions. Also closed are county courts, U.S. district courts, and Dania Beach's city hall. The city's Clerk's Office remains open for election-related business.\n\nThe city of Miami has announced that all city services at the Miami River Center, City Hall, parks, summer camps, and solid waste collection are suspended on Thursday.\n\nMiami-Dade public schools will be open for the summer session.\n\nFlorida International University's Biscayne Bay campus and the campus at I-75 are closed due to flooding. Nova Southeastern University's Oceanographic Center is also closed Thursday due to flooding.\n\nDue to flooding conditions on sections of the railroad, Tri-Rail service between Metrorail Transfer and MiamiCentral stations remains suspended Thursday morning. Passengers are advised to use the Metrorail system.\n\nMiami residents in need of sandbags can pick them up starting at 10 a.m. at Douglas Park at 2755 SW 37th Avenue. It's limited to five bags per resident and they must provide proof of residency. They will be available until the supply runs out.\n\nSandbags will be available at 11 a.m. at North Miami's public works facility at 1855 NE 142nd Street. Opa-locka is also distributing sandbags from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. at their public works department at 12950 NW 42nd Avenue.\n\nSeveral South Florida cities have received more than 15 inches of rain in the last two days.\n\nNorth Miami has received more than 20 inches, Hallandale Beach and Hollywood have received more than 19 inches, Davie has gotten nearly 18 inches, Dania Beach 10 inches, and Plantation nearly nine inches.\n\nIn Northeast Miami-Dade, a man who lives off NE 199th Street said he had to wade through waist deep water to get to his home.\n\n\"It's right where the entrance to where my apartment is. The water was up to here (motioning to his hips). I'm not kidding you. And there are a couple of cars stranded by the entrance. I'm freaking out because yesterday I was like how do I get around here, this is crazy, I don't know how long this is going to going on for,\" he said.\n\nA flood warning is in effect for much of Miami-Dade and Broward through 8 a.m. Thursday. A flood watch is in effect through Friday at 8 p.m.\n\nSome locations that will experience flooding include Miami, Hialeah, Fort Lauderdale, Pembroke Pines, Hollywood, Miramar, Pompano Beach, Davie, Miami Beach, Plantation, Sunrise, Tamarac, Margate, Coral Gables, Key Biscayne, South Miami, Lauderdale-By-The-Sea, Surfside, Miami Gardens and Hallandale Beach, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nThe wet, stormy weather pattern will hold in South Florida through the end of the work week, forecasters say, with the tropical moisture dissipating slightly by the weekend. Tropical rains have inundated major highways and roads and caused drivers to abandon their flooded vehicles.\n\nStorms have also delayed and canceled flights at Miami International Airport. Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport experienced flooding at entrances and exits and delayed dozens of flights.\n\nFOX 35 Orlando reported that passengers from South Florida have been arriving in droves on the Brightline train to Orlando International Airport since Wednesday.\n\nTickets for the high-speed passenger train from Miami and Fort Lauderdale that stops in Orlando were nearly sold out Thursday. Brightline officials told FOX 35 tickets were selling at a rate they have not seen since travel to Orlando opened last year.\n\nOne passenger told FOX 35 she saw flooding and stranded cars as she took the train out of South Florida.\n\n\"I was happy to take the train because it got me out of the craziness,\" she said.\n\nFLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY ISSUED FOR PARTS OF SOUTH FLORIDA AS TROPICAL DISTURBANCE 90L CROSSES STATE\n\nMore than 19 inches of rain was recorded in Aventura between Tuesday and Wednesday, with 15 inches falling on Wednesday alone. In some areas, including Hollywood, rainfall rates exceeded 5 inches per hour.\n\nBrightline has also faced delays because of the flooding in South Florida. The route includes five stops from West Palm Beach to Miami. On Wednesday, southbound trains could not go farther than Fort Lauderdale. Northbound trains from Miami and Aventura were also suspended.\n\nBrightline trains between Miami and Fort Lauderdale were delayed Thursday because of flooding, but resumed normal operations later in The \"particularly dangerous situation\" started to unfold ahead of the Wednesday evening commute.\n\n\"Please stay home if you possibly can and do not go wandering into flooded waters,\" Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava told Miami-based Local 10 News on Wednesday. \"We want people to just stay off the roads but we are pumping and we also have our emergency vehicles on the ready.\"\n\nNearly 20 inches had fallen in Hollywood and Hallandale Beach, according to AccuWeather/Ambient Weather stations. This is more than double the historical average rainfall for all of June and well above the 11.94 inches that fell in the region from January through May.\n\nWednesday afternoon's heavy rain in southeast Florida follows flooding reported on the west coast of the state yesterday. The Sarasota-Bradenton airport set a new preliminary record for 1-hour rainfall, racking up 3.93 inches between 7 and 8 p.m. EDT. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nThe National Weather Service estimates that from Tuesday through Wednesday about 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain deluged the hardest-hit spots, including Hallandale Beach and Hollywood, both near Fort Lauderdale, and roughly the same amount in North Miami.\n\nMiami Beach, which frequently floods in less powerful storms, got about 13 inches (33 centimeters).\n\nForecasts call for more rain Thursday that would likely cause additional flooding because the ground is already saturated.\n\nJune is typically the wettest month in Miami, with annual average rainfall of more than 10 inches (25 centimeters), said Alex DaSilva, AccuWeather's lead hurricane forecaster.\n\n\"What is unusual is how much rain South Florida has seen in such a short period of time,\" DaSilva said.\n\nIt has happened many times before. In one recent example, Fort Lauderdale was hit hard in April 2023 with record rainfall totals ranging from 15 inches (38 centimeters) to 26 inches (66 centimeters). {"uri": "2024-06-388521355", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:46:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:46:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:43:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.miamiherald.com/news/weather-news/article289238405.html", "title": "Flooding paralyzed South Florida roads and airports. More rain is on the way", "body": "Nearly 20 inches of rain pummeled South Florida over the last two days, clogging roads with feet of water and hundreds of stalled cars.\n\nThe state and multiple cities declared a state of emergency as floodwater poured into homes and businesses, stopped traffic on Interstate 95 and froze travel from both major airports.\n\nAnd it's not over yet. The forecast calls for another round of drenching rain Thursday afternoon, with another 2 to 4.5 inches of rain expected Thursday through Saturday.\n\n\"Don't be deceived by the sun peeking out from the clouds,\" Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava said at a morning press conference in the county's emergency operations center in Doral. \"We've seen clear skies this morning, but we are expecting heavy rainfall once again today.\"\n\nThe deluge continues to put pressure on the county's sewer system, with the downpours and rising groundwater levels forcing fresh water into sewer pipes. That risks overwhelming treatment plants that can only handle so much liquid on a given day. Levine Cava said residents could help by reducing water usage during peak morning hours and by following the law and not loosening manhole covers to create makeshift drains on the streets.\n\nCounty crews were out Wednesday creating temporary dams around sewage pump stations in flood-prone areas and deploying pumps to reduce street flooding.\n\nLevine Cava described a government largely functioning as normal on Thursday morning, despite an emergency declaration she issued the prior evening. No major roads are closed, and transit service continues as normal, with Wednesday's bus route detours around flooded streets now mostly lifted.\n\nAs of Thursday morning, State Farm reported more than 300 vehicular flood claims from South Florida so far, said spokesman Michal Brower.\n\n\"Majority of the auto claims are for flood damage, and number of claims reported could be expected to increase as rain is projected to continue today and tomorrow and additional drivers discover flood damage to vehicles,\" he wrote in a statement.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Miami office reported that more than 19 inches of rain fell between Tuesday and Wednesday in Hallandale Beach, which saw the worst of the flooding in Broward County on Wednesday, along with Hollywood.\n\nIn Miami-Dade, North Miami saw more than 20 inches of rain, and Miami Beach saw more than 13 inches over the two days.\n\nThat much rain was enough to sweep into homes up and down the coast, including Sam Demarco's house in Hollywood. Water seeped under his front door, and passing cars sent wakes that pushed the water even further inside.\n\n\"We were kind of ambushed today,\" he said Wednesday.\n\nAt that time, Demarco's front yard was knee-deep in water. He had a pile of towels in the hallway to his bedroom to make sure the flood water in his living room didn't reach it. Demarco's home was flooded in April 2023, destroying all of the furniture at the front of his house. Since then, he's moved most of his furniture to the back of the home to prepare for weather like this week's.\n\n\"I'm not giving up paradise for a little bad weather,\" Demarco said.", "source": {"uri": "miamiherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Miami Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alex_harris@miamiherald.com", "name": "Alex Harris", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": {"uri": "8175184942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "02:09:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T02:09:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T02:09:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://time.com/6988096/florida-storm-start-hurricane-season/", "title": "Florida Storm Marks Beginning of Hurricane Season", "body": "A Florida storm that led to flash floods, submerged roads, mass flight cancellations, stalled cars, and power outages on Wednesday is just the beginning of an active hurricane season, meteorologists said.\n\nTorrential rains hit South Florida on Tuesday and Wednesday, prompting officials to warn the public of \"life-threatening flooding\" in some areas, NBC News reported. The storm marks the start of the Atlantic hurricane season -- the latest start to the season since 2014, when the first storm did not hit until July 1, according to AccuWeather.\n\nDespite this year's late start, AccuWeather meteorologists predicted that 2024 would be a \"super-charged year for tropical systems,\" and expected \"multiple threats\" to the U.S., the Caribbean, and Central America.\n\nIn Florida, the National Weather Service (NWS) in Miami received reports of flash flooding from Fort Lauderdale to downtown Miami. The storm has dumped more than 10 inches of rain in some regions, The New York Times reported. AccuWeather estimated that the total rainfall in some parts of southwestern Florida could reach between 18 and 24 inches.\n\nThe NWS in Miami posted on X that many regions were \"inundated with water\" and stalled cars, and that even more rain was on the way.\n\nRead More: These Striking Photographs Capture the Aftermath of Florida's 1,000-Year Storm\n\nIn Hollywood, near Fort Lauderdale, drivers became trapped in their cars after driving on the flooded roads, NBC South Florida reported. Photos and videos of the flooding went viral on social media, with some footage showing cars nearly fully submerged underwater.\n\nThe NWS in Miami told the Times that it had not received any reports of injuries or deaths.\n\nThe storm also caused power outages, with Florida Power & Light reporting almost 300 outages in the area near Fort Lauderdale and Miami as of Wednesday evening. Both the Miami International Airport and the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport said that many flights were either delayed or canceled because of the storm.\n\nForecasters at the Weather Prediction Center told the Times that more flash flooding may continue to occur late Thursday morning and into the afternoon.\n\nAccuWeather meteorologists warned that the storm in Florida could be just the beginning. Meteorologists said they were watching several areas -- including off the southern Atlantic coast, through the Gulf of Mexico, and into the eastern Pacific -- through the rest of the month for potential tropical storms. AccuWeather said that there are \"currently no systems on the verge of developing,\" but added that weather conditions could change over the next week.", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": record-setting, 'life...", "body": "South Florida is expected to be soaked by another storm Thursday after \"life-threatening\" and record-setting flooding caused a state of emergency, forecasters said.\n\nPotentially dangerous heavy rains of up 4-8 inches are forecast with thunder through the afternoon, with some areas to be hit by up to 10 inches, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nThe wild weather comes after \"catastrophic and life-threatening flash flooding\" had already turned roads into waist-high rivers, stranding drivers and prompting dozens of rescues Wednesday.\n\nOn Thursday, the weather service issued an excessive rainfall advisory -- the most urgent flooding warning -- across parts of South Florida, including Miami.\n\n\"Don't be deceived by the sun that is peeking out from behind the clouds,\" Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava warned at a press conference Wednesday evening. \"If you can, stay home or indoors.\"\n\nOver the past two days, the downpour has totaled 20 inches in some parts of Miami-Dade County with the heaviest rainfall between 5pm and 8pm Wednesday.\n\nIn Sarasota, a record-setting 4 inches of rain fell in a single hour.\n\n\"That's the most ever in an hour,\" said David Parkinson, senior weather producer at CBS.\n\nIn total, Emergency responders have rescued at least 34 people who were trapped in vehicles and inside homes due to flooding, USA Today reported.\n\nThe storms also threaten to halt team USA's possible advancement to the Super 8 round of the T-20 Cricket World Cup.\n\nThe US is {"uri": "8173125080", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-11", "time": "20:32:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-11T20:32:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-11T20:32:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.tampabay.com/news/weather/2024/06/11/tampa-florida-weather-for-tomorrow-rain-flooding/", "title": "What to expect from the rain in Tampa Bay this week", "body": "Forecasters are monitoring a patch of weather in the Gulf of Mexico. Here's what to know.\n\nA messy glob of tropical moisture sitting near Florida's west coast will bring a mix of rain and humidity to Tampa Bay this week.\n\nOn Tuesday, forecasters with the National Hurricane Center said it was watching the rough patch for possible tropical development. But they said that was unlikely and wouldn't occur until days from now, after the weather had passed over Florida and into the Atlantic Ocean.\n\n\"Regardless of development, heavy rainfall is expected across portions of Florida during the next few days,\" according to the hurricane center.\n\nEarlier forecasts called for as much as 10 inches of rain in the Tampa Bay area, but on Tuesday the amount of forecasted rainfall declined. The National Weather Service said it anticipates up to 6 inches in Tampa Bay through Friday and 8 inches through Sunday.\n\nSouthwest Florida is expected to get even more rain -- up to 15 inches in Fort Myers, for instance -- and forecasters are warning of possible flooding and rising rivers in that part of the state.\n\nRainfall in the Tampa Bay area is welcome news. For weeks, the area has sweltered under record-breaking heat and a drought (though typical for this time of year). Should the rainfall remain manageable and spread out, meteorologists say it will be beneficial for Tampa Bay.\n\nSo what can Florida -- and Tampa Bay -- expect from the blob of moisture during its long, leisurely stay? Here's a breakdown of what to know.\n\nThe area of rough weather is being described as a \"plume of tropical moisture,\" according to Spectrum Bay News 9.\n\nIt extends from the Caribbean Sea, spreading toward the eastern Gulf of Mexico and into the Florida peninsula, said Ross Giarratana, a meteorologist from the National Weather Service's Tampa Bay office.\n\nThink of it as a firehose of soggy air being transported straight from the tropics.\n\n\"Any of these storms and showers that develop really will have some high rainfall totals in a short period of time,\" Giarratana said.\n\nThe hurricane center said in a Tuesday afternoon forecast that the patch of weather has just a 10% chance of tropical development by Thursday and a 20% chance over the next week.\n\nThis Atlantic season has yet to see a named storm. It's the slowest start to hurricane season in more than a decade. The first named storm will be called Alberto.\n\nHowever, top hurricane academics Tuesday said the sleeping giant will soon awaken.\n\nIn their June forecast update, researchers at Colorado State University maintained their initial forecast for an \"extremely active\" Atlantic hurricane season. The renowned climate school in April predicted 11 hurricanes would spin up this season, the most ever expected in the institution's nearly three decades of early season forecasting.\n\nIt has been two months since their initial prediction, and university experts are sticking with that number. Record-warm Atlantic temperatures and an arriving La Ni\u00f1a weather pattern are to blame, researchers said.\n\nWhile forecasters anticipated rainfall amounts up to 10 inches in Tampa Bay earlier this week, Kyle Hanson, a meteorologist for Spectrum Bay News 9, said the moisture has shifted further south and likely won't cause as much rain here.\n\nHanson said rainfall is likely to come in patches for the next few days.\n\n\"It'll start raining for a half an hour, then it'll stop, and that can happen again at some point in the day,\" Hanson said. \"Then it'll just be kind of off and on like that through about Friday.\"\n\nA flood advisory was issued for a portion of southwest Pasco and northern Pinellas counties Tuesday afternoon, when heavy rains were expected to cause urban and small stream flooding. Additionally, portions of South Florida are under a flood watch through Wednesday night.\n\nThe weather service's Southeast River Forecast Center is expecting heavy rains in Central and South Florida could produce minor flooding, and even flash floods in some areas.\n\nThe Manatee River at State Road 64 is expected to reach 10.5 feet on Thursday. Minor flooding begins at 11 feet. The Myakka River at Myakka State Park will, at 6.9 feet, be a hair away from minor flooding, which occurs at 7 feet.\n\nHorse Creek near Arcadia was expected to reach a minor flooding stage at 13.8 feet.\n\nGiarratana said the weather service is watching for areas that receive multiple rounds of rain, especially urban areas, which are most vulnerable to flooding.\n\nAreas with concrete and buildings rely more heavily on drainage systems as opposed to green areas that can naturally soak up water.\n\nShould flooding occur, you should not walk or drive through waters. It takes just six inches of moving water to knock a person off their feet, the weather service said.\n\nFlood water also may be deeper than it appears, and can hide sharp objects, electrical wires and chemicals, the weather service said. If you find yourself caught in flood waters, get to the highest ground possible and call 911.\n\nThe rain the area is experiencing this week is not uncommon for this time of year, Hanson from Bay News 9 said.\n\n\"We're due for this,\" Hanson said. \"We haven't had an event like this yet this year.\"\n\nThe rainfall expected in south Florida is less likely, Hanson said. However, because of the area's proximity to the tropics, it can happen every so often.\n\n\"It's certainly an event, and certainly something that does not happen often -- you could say this is like a once a year type of event,\" Hanson said.\n\nWhile the rainfall amounts are high, they'll be over multiple days in a widespread area, which should lower the chance of flooding.\n\nThe showers won't be like last year, when 25 inches of rain fell on Fort Lauderdale in a single day, flooding streets and stalling cars. That kind of rainfall is more like a once every 1,000 years occurrence.\n\nBecause of the drought, the ground should be able to soak up the water. When the ground is more saturated, it becomes more difficult for the ground to slurp up rain water.\n\nThe United States drought monitor shows portions of Tampa Bay are running from abnormally dry to a moderate drought. Areas to the south, like Manatee and Sarasota counties, are in a severe drought.\n\nAccording to the Southwest Water Management District, from Jan. 1 to June 9, the district-wide rainfall deficit was about 10 inches.\n\n\"The area's current low water levels will certainly benefit from the forecasted rain this week,\" the water management district said in an email to the Tampa Bay Times.\n\nHanson said the rain may not entirely pull the area out of a drought, but he expects more rain in the near future. The rainy season may settle in after this week's storms pass through.\n\n\"From here on out,\" Hanson said, \"we're going to see more wet weather than we have been seeing previously.\"", "source": {"uri": "8176607463", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:41:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:41:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:27:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/south-floridians-brace-themselves-second-191200817.html", "title": "South Floridians brace themselves for second day of flooding as system approaches", "body": "Amid a brief lull in the weather Thursday, already flood-weary South Floridians are bracing themselves for another round of heavy rain and flash floods as a line of storms approaches the region.\n\nA frontal boundary stationed near parts of central and southwest Florida is gradually making its way south and will likely cause more flooding in areas that were already inundated on Wednesday, though forecasters can't say exactly what areas will be most affected.\n\nThe National Weather Service Miami has issued a \"high risk of excessive flooding\" warning, a rare warning only for situations in which widespread flash flooding is likely and potentially \"catastrophic\" in some areas.\n\nFuture radar shows the heaviest bands of the system approaching during rush hour.\n\nThe beginnings of the weather could be felt late Thursday afternoon. A strong thunderstorm was headed towards inland parts of Broward and Palm Beach counties just before 3 p.m., bringing winds as high as 30 mph.\n\nThe City of Fort Lauderdale told residents in a 3 p.m. update that the city is anticipating 10 to 12 inches of rain from 3 to 7 p.m. as storms roll through.\n\n\"The groundwater table is nearly saturated,\" the city wrote on X. \"This will create flooding conditions very quickly.\"\n\nIn Wednesday's hard-hit cities, including Hallandale Beach, Hollywood, Fort Lauderdale, and Dania Beach, crews worked to pump water, and even some residents helped to de-clog drains along flooded streets before the rain begins again. Many drains are clogged Thursday following Wednesday's storms, officials say. Meanwhile, tow trucks have continued to work since Wednesday to remove dozens of cars from the roads.\n\nBuildings were also affected. Hallandale Beach shut down its City Hall because of flooding as of 2:30 p.m., Mayor Joy Cooper wrote on Facebook.\n\n\"This will allow for residents currently at City Hall to conclude their business and hopefully make it home safely,\" she said.\n\nIn Miramar, several homes were flooded with up to 8 inches of water, city officials said.\n\nCity officials from Hollywood, Dania Beach, Hallandale and Fort Lauderdale said it was too early to say how many homes were damaged. But some residents have already reported flooding in Dania Beach and Fort Lauderdale, though largely not to the same extent as April 2023.\n\nIn Wilton Manors, resident Boyd Corbin reported seeing sewage bubbling out of manhole covers in the street.\n\nSouth Florida's passenger rail services had returned to close to normal earlier in the day, but air travelers continued to suffer protracted delays and large numbers of flight cancellations as heavy rains again hindered the region's transportation system.\n\nBrightline, the high-speed rail service, started the day with a modified schedule after floodwaters made a mile-long stretch of tracks between Aventura and Miami impassable late Wednesday along the Florida East Coast Railway corridor.\n\nTri-Rail, the three-county commuter service that runs west of Interstate 95 through Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade counties, reopened its connection to MiamiCentral station in downtown Miami.\n\nBut it was another day of inconveniences and frustration at South Florida's three international airports as passengers again faced hours-long waits triggered by bad weather.\n\nFort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport and Miami International Airport advised passengers to check with their airlines for flight status updates before leaving for their air terminals.\n\n\"Our terminal & airport exit roadways are clear, but a section of E, Perimeter Rd. into #FLL is closed due to flooding; use alternate routes,\" the airport declared on its X account.\n\nShortly after midday Thursday, Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood had 182 delays and 116 cancellations, Miami International had 186 delays and 269 cancellations, while Palm Beach International had nominal numbers of delays and canceled flights, according to the flight tracking site FlightAware.\n\nPort Everglades said it has remained open for business during the bad weather even though some of its roads flooded. Cars and trucks on Wednesday were able to travel through the port, said spokeswoman Joy Oglesby.\n\n\"We are operating as normal today,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", With a stationary front to the north, tropical moisture is being pulled in from the south.\n\nThe bottom line is South Florida is stuck with this wet, stormy weather pattern through the end of the work week. It looks like the deepest of the tropical moisture will be dissipating a bit more by the weekend. That will leave us a little bit drier, but there will still be a chance for storms but not nearly as widespread.\n\nOver the past 24 hours, Miami Beach saw nearly 7 inches of rain, Hallandale Beach 6 inches, Hollywood, North Miami, and Coral Gables received just over 5 inches.\n\nThe good news is the average 4 to 6 inches of rain that fell Tuesday squashed the rainfall deficit in Miami and put a good dent in Broward's deficit.\n\nThe bad news is that an additional 4 to 8 inches is possible over the next few days and flooding is an increasing concern.\n\nAfter an early morning lull on Wednesday, storm activity is expected to pick up mid-morning through the early afternoon. {"uri": "8176321161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:40:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:40:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T15:39:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2024/06/13/florida-flooding-rainfall-totals-storm-forecast/", "title": "How much rain fell in Florida? Is there more coming?", "body": "The National Weather Service issued a dire flash flood emergency for \"catastrophic\" flood impacts between Miami Dade and Fort Lauderdale.\n\nThe episode comes 14 months to the day since an incredible 22.5 inches fell on Fort Lauderdale/Hollywood International Airport in a single day, leading to unprecedented flood impacts. Both episodes bear the fingerprint of human-caused climate change, which is increasing the intensity and severity of top-tier rain events.\n\nTo make matters worse, the ongoing rain event is far from over, and another half-foot or more of rain could fall in some spots before downpours finally wind down into Friday. In some areas, roadways are still impassable due to high water.\n\nHere's how much rain fell just on Wednesday:\n\nIf we look at what has fallen since Monday morning, there are a few totals closing in on 18 inches:\n\nA number of records were set across the area. Wednesday's 9.54 inches nabs the top spot for the wettest summer day on record, surpassing the 8.6 inches that fell on June 2, 1930. It's the eighth wettest day at the airport of all time.\n\nA typical June averages 9.55 inches of rain, meaning an entire month's worth of rain came down in one day.\n\nBetween 1 and 2 p.m. Eastern time Wednesday, 2.41 inches of rain fell. That's the seventh wettest hour on record at Fort Lauderdale/Hollywood International Airport. Hourly weather observations date back to 1973, but seven of the wettest hours on record have occurred in the past 10 years, and all have occurred since 2003.\n\nOne station in Hollywood, Fla., logged 10.22 inches of rain in six hours, which statistically falls just shy of a hundred-year rain event, or an event that has a 1 percent chance of happening in a given location any given year. Sunny Isles Beach got 6.47 inches in 3 hours, which occurs on average once every 25 years.\n\nIt's well established that the frequency, and intensity, of rainfall events in increasing in tandem with our warming atmosphere. A warmer world is a wetter world, since warmer air has a greater propensity to hold water. For every degree of increase in heat in the atmosphere, it can hold 4 percent more moisture.\n\nThat's why extremes like this are becoming more common, and rainfall rates are getting heavier too. Moreover, a more saturated atmosphere during high-end events increases precipitation efficiency; in other words, more of the raindrops survive to the ground without evaporating, leading to more rapid accumulations.\n\nWeather models depict continued shower and thunderstorm activity across South Florida on Thursday afternoon and evening, with the chance that another 3 to 6 inches falls. Localized greater totals can't be ruled out.\n\nThe rainfall won't extend much north of a line from Punta Gorda to the Space Coast, though a renegade afternoon shower or thunderstorm is possible.\n\nBy Friday afternoon, only typical late-day summertime storms are expected. The parent low-pressure system will be pulling into the northwest Atlantic, where it has a low-end chance of acquiring subtropical characteristics as it passes over the warm waters or the Gulf Stream. According to the National Hurricane Center, the system has a 20 percent chance of development.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-386161785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-11", "time": "15:28:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-11T15:28:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-11T15:25:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/map-shows-florida-cities-getting-monthly-rainfall-days-1911306", "title": "Map shows Florida cities getting monthly rainfall in days", "body": "At least six Florida cities are expected to receive their average monthly rainfall in only four days, according to a map from the National Weather Service.\n\nA plume of moisture from the Caribbean is bringing excessive rain to the Sunshine State this week. The rain is expected to be heaviest from Wednesday to Friday, with the NWS warning that flooding could begin as early as Tuesday and continue into the weekend.\n\nIn May, cities in southern Florida broke heat records, and last week, the state and much of the southern United States -- including Texas, Arizona and southern California -- experienced extreme heat.\n\nOn Monday morning, the NWS office for Florida's Tampa Bay area shared a map that showed rainfall estimates through Friday. According to the map, multiple locations could receive at least 6 inches of rain, although some areas could see much more. Fort Myers is expecting the most rain, with the forecast anticipating 15 to 20 inches from the storm. The city's average monthly rainfall in June is 9.66 inches, meaning this week could produce more than double the month's average precipitation.\n\nOther Florida cities expecting to receive at least their average June rainfall this week include Belle Glade, Immokalee, West Palm Beach, Punta Gorda and Sarasota. Records show that the average June rainfall for each of those cities is as follows: 9.49 inches in Belle Glade, 8 inches in Immokalee, 8.48 inches in West Palm Beach, 9.24 inches in Punta Gorda and 7.05 inches in Sarasota.\n\nAccording to the NWS map, each of those cities is expected to receive at least 8 inches of rain this week. Others are anticipating even more, including Immokalee and Punta Gorda, where 10 to 15 inches of rain is forecast.\n\nLuke Culver, an NWS meteorologist, told Newsweek that every few years, Florida cities experience a rainstorm that produces their monthly average rainfall in only a few days. He warned that people in the affected areas should be alert for flooding.\n\n\"Conditions are favorable for potential localized flash flooding, so have a way to be able to get those warnings if we issue any and be able to take action,\" he said.\n\nAs of Tuesday morning, a flood watch was in place for much of southern Florida. However, much of the region has experienced dry weather, meaning streams are low and primed to receive heavy rain.\n\nRoss Giarratana, an NWS meteorologist, told Newsweek that widespread rain has already begun falling across the state. The heaviest amounts so far have been experienced in southwest Florida, he said, specifically in Lee County and Sarasota County. Ron DeSantis, the state has experienced widespread heavy rainfall with totals of 10 to 15 inches. The torrential downpours are a result of Invest 90-L, an elongated area of low pressure that the National Hurricane Center has been tracking this week. It moved off the east coast on Wednesday night but is expected to continue bringing storms to Florida as the week closes out.RELATED: Invest 90-L moves off Florida coast, formation chance in Gulf of Mexico increases According to DeSantis, preliminary reports indicate that the rainfall and flooding have affected the ability of critical infrastructure to operate -- including major interstates, roadways, airports, schools and more.Video from Broward County shows cars stalling out on roads and people walking in water that goes up to their knees.Because the severe downpours are expected to continue, the state is worried about Invest 90-L's ability to exacerbate current flooding conditions in vulnerable metropolitan areas.The Florida Division of Emergency Management will help the state respond to the flooding. The governor's executive order is effective immediately and will expire in 60 days unless otherwise extended.>> READ ALSO: Confirmed tornado rips through South Florida, uprooting trees and damaging buildings>> Track storms with WESH 2's radar\n\nSevere flooding caused by tropical downpours in the southern portion of Florida has prompted the governor to declare a state of emergency for multiple counties.\n\nBroward, Collier, Lee, Miami-Dade and Sarasota counties are all under a state of emergency after more than eight inches of rain fell on Wednesday and even more is on tap for the rest of the week.\n\nAccording to an executive order released by Gov. Ron DeSantis, the state has experienced widespread heavy rainfall with totals of 10 to 15 inches.\n\nThe torrential downpours are a result of Invest 90-L, an elongated area of low pressure that the National Hurricane Center has been tracking this week. That's pulled a deep plume of moisture from Central America and the Caribbean Sea into the peninsula,\" weather.com senior meteorologist Jonathan Erdman said.\n\n(MORE: The Latest Forecast For Florida Flooding, Possible Tropical Development)\n\nPeople are being asked to stay put.\n\n\"Most of all we want residents to know to stay safe, to stay inside, to avoid flooded areas and to remain vigilant,\" Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava said in a morning news conference.\n\nPeople were asked to stay off the roads in Broward and Miami-Dade Counties.\n\nBroward Sheriff Gregory Tony said in a social media update Wednesday that 911 call centers were being inundated with non-emergency calls related to the weather.\n\nState Of Emergency Declared For Millions Of People, Hundreds Of Flights Canceled\n\nFlorida Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for Miami-Dade, Broward, Lee, Collier and Sarasota counties. Miami-Dade and Broward, which includes the city of Fort Lauderdale, are the state's two largest counties with more than 4.5 million people combined.\n\nLocal officials also declared states of emergency in Miami, Fort Lauderdale and Sunny Isles Beach.\n\nSchool facilities are closed in Broward County, including all summer camps. Florida Atlantic University closed its campuses in Davie and Fort Lauderdale, and Florida A&M's Davie campus moved to remote learning.\n\nAbout 500 hundred flights were canceled or delayed as of 11 a.m. Thursday at Miami and Fort Lauderdale international airports, according to airline tracker FlightAware.com. More than 1,200 flights were impacted Wednesday.\n\nFlight delays were also reported at airports in Palm Beach, Fort Myers and Orlando.\n\n\"There is some light at the end of this wet tunnel. This conveyor belt of moisture should retreat westward by this weekend, taking the threat of widespread heavy rain with it,\" Erdman said.\n\n\"Expect some scattered showers and storms this weekend, but of the variety more typical for a Florida summer day.\"\n\nMORE ON WEATHER.COM\n\n-El Ni\u00f1o Officially Ends With La Ni\u00f1a Likely To Develop In Coming Months\n\nWeather.com reporter Jan {"uri": "8176629250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:51:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:51:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:48:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://theprint.in/environment/unrelenting-rain-puts-south-florida-at-risk-of-life-threatening-flooding/2130656/", "title": "Unrelenting rain puts South Florida at risk of 'life-threatening' flooding", "body": "A few spots have reported up to 18-to-25 inches (46-to-63.5 cm) of rain since Monday, said Bob Oravec, a forecaster with the service's Weather Prediction Center in College Park, Maryland.\n\nNorth Miami Beach was near the top of the list for rainfall on Thursday with 20.4 inches of rain since Monday, said Oravec, while Big Cypress National Preserve in the Everglades was awash with about 25 inches.\n\nIn Hallandale Beach, which has been inundated by 19.3 inches of precipitation, resident Luis Garcia Infante said he had never experienced such a deluge in his 13 years of living in the community in south Broward County.\n\n\"There's been rain, heavy rain, but never, never like this,\" Infante said. \"This is extreme.\"\n\nThe slow-moving storm -- a disorganized tropical depression drawing its strength from warm Gulf Coast and Atlantic waters -- is expected to linger over the state until early Saturday before pushing out to sea, Oravec said.\n\nEven though the system is not expected to strengthen into a tropical storm, it could be a wet prelude to what is expected to be a busy hurricane season, which began on June 1.\n\nWith another 5 inches of rain possible before Friday night, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for five South Florida Counties late on Wednesday.\n\nMedia reports and social media posts showed stalled cars and people wading in streets covered in hip-deep water, or paddling in small boats and kayaks. In some areas water has swamped lawns and pushed up to the front doors of houses and other buildings.\n\nParts of Interstate 95, a main north-south route along the East Coast, were closed due to flooding on Wednesday.\n\n\"The problem is that there is no place for the rain to go,\" said Oravec. \"The ground is so saturated. In some places water is rising up from the sewers.\"\n\nIn nearby Fort Lauderdale, Mayor Dean Trantalis declared a city-wide emergency due to flooding. He said the Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission was sending boats and high-water vehicles to assist any rescues if needed.\n\nTrantalis urged people to stay off roadways. \"It's crucial to never attempt to drive through high water,\" he warned in a message on the X social media platform.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also declared states of emergency, freeing up money and resources to better cope with the storm and its aftermath.\n\nForecasters are expecting eight to 13 hurricanes in the Atlantic this season, seven of which could build into major storms. Overall, some 17 to 25 named tropical storms are expected.\n\nAn average hurricane season produces about 14 named storms, of which seven become hurricanes.\n\nIn recent years, the frequency and intensity of hurricanes have increased linked to warming sea temperatures caused by higher carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta; Editing by Frank McGurty, {"uri": "8175239033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "03:16:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T03:16:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T03:15:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/currentnews/newsheadlines/s-3284944", "title": "'We're prepared for the worst': South Floridians weather 'rare' flash flood emergency", "body": "MIAMI -- Life-threatening rainfall pummeling South Florida that's closed I-95 and caused major delays at the region's two largest airports Wednesday was considered a flash flood emergency -- an \"exceedingly rare\" circumstance classified by forecasters when catastrophic damage is imminent.\n\nAround 3:40 p.m., the National Weather Service issued a flash flood emergency for portions of southern Broward County and northern Miami-Dade County. The emergency was in effect until 8:00 pm.\n\nCities under the emergency advisory were: Miami Gardens, North Miami Beach, Pembroke Pines, Hollywood, Miramar and Dania Beach. Other urban city centers in both counties were forecast to see the greatest threat of flash flooding.\n\nForecasters said they've received \"nonstop\" reports of flash flooding. At one point, the NWS had six flash flood warnings in effect throughout the region.\n\nResidents were told not to drive in the emergency area and to seek higher ground until flood waters receded.\n\nSo far this week, parts of South Florida have seen up to at least 10 inches of rain.\n\nWhat is a flash flood emergency?\n\nA flash flood emergency is the most severe weather category for flooding. An emergency is only issued in exceedingly rare situations when extremely heavy rain is leading to a severe threat to life and catastrophic damage, the weather service said.\n\nLuke Culver, a meteorologist at NWS Miami, said the emergency \"is really for extremely rare situations where there are dangers to life and property.\"\n\n\"When we go to an emergency, we have people getting rescued {"uri": "2024-06-387114776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "11:49:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T11:49:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T11:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/invest-90l-rainfall-florida/61082176", "title": "Rainfall totals skyrocket in Florida as Invest 90-L brings plenty of showers", "body": "The National Hurricane Center is tracking a trough of low pressure -- dubbed Invest 90-L -- that is triggering plenty of showers in Central Florida and beyond.Some southern locations have seen rainfall amounts topping 9 inches this week alone. While the highest amount of rainfall has trended towards the southern portion of the state, Central Florida has certainly gotten its fair share of showers. Residents in West Titusville have seen just under 6.5 inches of rain this week. In Canaveral N. Seashore, the rainfall amount is at 6.30 inches for the week. The University of Central Florida saw 3.66 inches this week and Mims saw 3 inches.The amount of rain triggered a flood advisory in Volusia County on Tuesday night, and caused serious flash flooding in other parts of the state. While rainfall in Central Florida was high, the numbers farther south are even more staggering. In Bradenton, rainfall amounts are nearing 10 inches for the week. North Sarasota has seen 7.79 inches of rain this week, and Everglades City follows close behind with a weekly total of 7.75 inches. North Miami has seen 6.69 inches.Tracking the Tropics: What's an invest? Invest 90-L started in the Gulf of Mexico and has slowly worked its way toward the western coast of Florida since being tagged by the NHC on Tuesday. It is expected to move across the state and off the southeastern coast as the week continues. According to the NHC, the invest has a very small chance of forming (10% in the next 48 hours and 20% in the next seven days). Formation is most likely once the low-pressure area moves off the Florida coast.Invest is short for \"investigation\" and refers to a weather feature that the NHC is investigating. It should be noted that it is not necessarily an area that is expected to develop into a tropical system. It's simply an area being investigated for any number of reasons.>>> Related: WESH 2 Hurricane Survival Guide 2024>>> Related: Surviving the Season | 2024 Hurricane Special from WESH 2\n\nThe National Hurricane Center is tracking a trough of low pressure -- dubbed Invest 90-L -- that is triggering plenty of showers in Central Florida and beyond.\n\nSome southern locations have seen rainfall amounts topping 9 inches this week alone.\n\nWhile the highest amount of rainfall has trended towards the southern portion of the state, Central Florida has certainly gotten its fair share of showers. North Miami has seen 6.69 inches.\n\nTracking the Tropics: What's an invest?\n\nInvest 90-L started in the Gulf of Mexico and has slowly worked its way toward the western coast of Florida since being tagged by the NHC on Tuesday. It is expected to move across the state and off the southeastern coast as the week continues.\n\nAccording to the NHC, the invest has a very small chance of forming (10% in the next 48 hours and 20% in the next seven days). Formation is most likely once the low-pressure area moves off the Florida coast.\n\nInvest is short for \"investigation\" and refers to a weather feature that the NHC is investigating. {"uri": "8174941082", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "21:08:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T21:08:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T21:08:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/152920/rainfall-breaks-records-in-florida", "title": "Rainfall Breaks Records in Florida", "body": "A plume of moisture from the western Caribbean delivered heavy rainfall to parts of southern Florida, particularly along its Gulf Coast, in June 2024. Intense precipitation from a slow-moving storm system triggered flash flood warnings and inundated roadways, while several cities set new daily precipitation records for June 11. Statistically, an event this severe should only occur once every 500 to 1,000 years, said meteorologists.\n\nThe map above shows rainfall accumulation for the 24-hour period starting at 00:00 Universal Time on June 11 (8 p.m. local time on June 10). These data are remotely-sensed estimates that come from IMERG (the Integrated Multi-Satellite Retrievals for GPM), a product of the GPM (Global Precipitation Measurement) mission, and may differ from ground-based measurements. For instance, IMERG data are averaged across each pixel, meaning that rain-gauge measurements within a given pixel can be significantly higher or lower than the average.\n\nSome of the highest rainfall totals were recorded in coastal Sarasota County. A National Weather Service (NWS) station in Sarasota measured 6.5 inches (16.5 centimeters) of rain for the 24 hours of June 11 (local time), breaking that date's record of 2.5 inches, set in 1940. Nearby locations saw up to 10 inches that day, according to NWS Tampa Bay. The rain was intense at times; a record 3.9 inches fell in one hour around 7 p.m. local time at the Sarasota-Bradenton Airport, toppling the previous hourly rainfall record by nearly an inch. Normal precipitation for the entire month of June is 7 inches.\n\nFarther south along the coast, Fort Myers and Naples set new records for precipitation on June 11. Miami verged on record-rainfall territory, according to NWS measurements, and the inclement weather caused hundreds of flight delays and dozens of cancellations at the Miami and Fort Lauderdale airports, according to news reports.\n\nForecasters called for bouts of heavy rainfall and a risk of localized flash flooding across Florida over the next several days as tropical moisture continues to stream in and converge with a stationary front to the north. The rain brought some relief to drought conditions that had developed across central and south Florida.", "source": {"uri": "earthobservatory.nasa.gov", "dataType": "news", "title": "NASA Earth {"uri": "8176435122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:02:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:02:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:00:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13527381/South-Florida-braced-life-threatening-floods-days-rain.html", "title": "South Florida braced for 'life-threatening' floods after days of rain", "body": "By Rich McKay\n\nJune 13 (Reuters) - More torrential downpours deluged South Florida on Thursday, adding to more than a foot of rain that fell on parts of the state this week and leading forecasters to issue flood watches or warnings for an area where 8 million people reside.\n\nSome areas, including portions of Broward and Miami-Dade counties, are threatened with \"life-threatening flooding,\" the National Weather Service said.\n\nA few spots have reported up to 18-to-25 inches of rain since Monday, said Bob Oravec, a forecaster with the service's Weather Prediction Center in College Park, Maryland.\n\nThe slow-moving storm - a disorganized tropical depression drawing its strength from warm Gulf Coast and Atlantic waters - is expected to linger over the state until early Saturday before pushing out to sea, Oravec said.\n\nEven though the system is not expected to strengthen into a tropical storm, it could be a wet prelude to what is expected to be a busy hurricane season, which got underway on June 1.\n\nWith another 5 inches of rain possible before Friday night, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for five South Florida Counties late on Wednesday.\n\nMedia reports and social media posts showed stalled cars and people wading in streets covered in hip-deep water, or paddling in small boats and kayaks. In some areas water has swamped lawns and pushed up to the front doors of houses and other buildings.\n\nParts of Interstate 95, a main north-south route along the East Coast, were closed due to flooding on Wednesday.\n\n\"The problem is that there is no place for the rain to go,\" said Oravec. \"The ground is so saturated. In some places water is rising up from the sewers.\"\n\nThe storm led officials to postpone the demolition of the building at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida where 17 students and staff were killed in February 2018 in one of the worst mass shootings in U.S. history.\n\nThe building, some parts still bloodstained, was closed immediately after the shooting and fenced off to preserve evidence. The demolition has been rescheduled for Friday.\n\nIn nearby Fort Lauderdale, Mayor Dean Trantalis declared a city-wide emergency due to flooding. He said the Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission was sending boats and high-water vehicles to assist any rescues if needed.\n\nTrantalis urged people to stay off roadways. \"It's crucial to never attempt to drive through high water,\" he warned in a message on the X social media platform.\n\nMiami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava also declared states of emergency, freeing up money and resources to better cope with the storm and its aftermath.\n\nHURRICANE FORECAST\n\nForecasters are expecting eight to 13 hurricanes in the Atlantic this season, seven of which could build into major storms. Overall some 17 to 25 named tropical storms are expected.\n\nAn average hurricane season produces about 14 named storms, of which seven become hurricanes.\n\nIn recent years, the frequency and intensity of hurricanes has increased linked to warming sea temperatures caused by higher carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.\n\n(Reporting by Rich McKay in Atlanta; Editing by Frank McGurty, Kirsten Donovan)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_cyclone", "type":
